The Judges have declared they will stay within the walls and protect the citizenry and the Emperor, but they will not participate in the vanguard. They also prevent Evan from bring on the frontlines, which bothers Evan as he wishes to fight alongside his friends once more, but even the party convinces him to remain at Pillars of Archons for his own safety.
The party discusses their next set of plans, but then they express to Evan that he needs to buy some paintings, specifically from a tiefling with a hooked hand.
During their time waiting for the attack and preparing defences as they desire, Antilean requests some raw materials, and begins to experiment in creating a new firearm. He runs out of time creating a coach gun, but manages to set up a simple rifle and a secondary simple pistol. He also sets up blueprints and engineering plans for sniping towers to assist in the defense in the town along the northern wall
Ronpip obtains a set of additional armor pieces to complete his half plate armor set, with the inclusion of the Adamantine Breastplate. He also helps provide additional gnome trigonometry to make sure the trebuchets have their accuracy and efficiency maximized. At the end of the downtime, Ronpip educates some engineers and takes some scouts to trap the edge of the woods, knowing that is where the elven army will be coming. He leaves a marked trail in gnomish to ensure the scouts he took with him could come back without setting them off.
Vimack stay with the citizenry and keeps their moral high during this time of chaos, keeping them from rebelling against forced evacuation from their homes and the potential dangers coming for them. He joins a group of scouts who intend to obtain information on strength and numbers of the elven army, potentially giving them an advantage in knowing how soon they come and how strong they are. The group and Vimack manage to find the army encampment, almost running directly into them as they are camping directly in the woods, as well as using magical fog to obscure their position. Vimack takes note, lying still in a strategic position. A majority of what Vimack can assume is vanguard is unarmoured, unarmed, and undead. The others among the army appear to be High Elven soldiers with Long Swords, Long Bows, and Spears. The other half of the army are composed of cultists similar to the ones encountered at House Paramoure, accompanied with war dogs. They have a set of unique trebuchets unique to the High Elven engineering, prepared for a siege. Vimack and his group have been carefully gleaning this information over the course of days, keeping hidden and still to the best of their abilities. On the final day, before the armies continued their travel, Vimack quickly takes out 11 of those siege weapons before the alarm was raised and he and the scouts had to escape. They return to the city, and relay the information they've acquired, as well as the successful sabotage of the siege weaponry, despite it not being 100%.
3 weeks have passed from the time they've returned from Phocelles. It has been quiet and tense for a few more days, before the snow falls from the darkened sky and a war horn from the North, as a elven army struts forward towards their direction.
And the siege upon the Northern Wall of Vasaaros happens in Session 20...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Session 20
item.description:
Following Session 19, Ronpip Thimble-bimble, Antilean Faraday, and Vimack Badger wait in anticipation, knowing the Elven Army is nigh about to approach. But, just as Hysseld predicted, as soon as the first snowflake fell over the the wall, the army crossed the forest. They see that Druids of Winter have changed the weather, forced snow clouds to converge and cover the area, as a blast of frigid cold air rushes to the city, through the northern town, up the defensive north wall, and across the targeted city.
Antilean hangs back, staying in a sniper tower and tries to provide support as best as he can. Vimack chooses to run with the Vanguard, as does Ronpip with Horsemen. Together, with the combined forces of Elven forces, Treants , and the forward armies of Vasaaros, they prepare their defense and counter attack.
From the forest where a snowblind strikes against the northern front, a rushing swarm of undead break through the treeline, hollering in bloodlust as they rush through the empty farmlands. Ronpip, from his experience in large scale battles, notices that the zombies are not the only thing charging in. Behind them, packs of armored dogs are racing behind their heels, though their target is obviously not the undead they trail. Trailing the war hounds, cultist war champions run behind them. However, the High Elves remain in formation at the far end of the battle field and do not charge forward. Vimack can make out among the High Elves their leader, adorned in golden armor and a blood red cape, and Priestess Yurreina Paramoure on either side of the rear guard, with Druids of Winter performing a ritual between them.
As the pack of zombies rush forward, Arcaedian archers fire in formation, aiming to lower their numbers before the vanguard have to meet them in melee combat. Trebuchets fire in tandem, with the West Trebuchets firing upon the druids performing a Winter Rite. Snow and Dirt blast into the air on impact of the payloads, and zombies fall to some of the volleys of arrows. The Druids finish a portion of their Rite, and a blast of flash frozen air crash into the Arcaedian defense.
Antilean preps his Invisibility Seeing device, which takes a hot minute to set up, but sees nothing that would have escaped his normal vision. Vimack and Ronpip charge in against the zombie horde with their respective squadrons. The Treants awaken, drive their roots into the earth and awaken nearby trees to joins the fight. Warhounds that weave between the zombies go for Ronpip, who attempts to parry their attacks with his skill with his greatsword. Antilean releases Dragoon to join the fray and help while he remains at the tower. With his heigh advantage, he picks off important targets at an incredible distance.
Suddenly, a plan comes to his mind, and he tells the archers around him to just keep shooting, while he slides down the tower wall with his claws and proceeds forth into the vanguard, whistling for Dragoon to return to him.
The fight draws out for several minutes; with neither side seeming to budge. The defense at the wall holds, despite the blasts of winter winds buffeting the soldiers and a tireless, undead enemy rushing in first. But the trio manages to keep morale high, charging into danger and keeping the legions at bay. The bear warriors that came to assist the defense, and morph themselves into werebears, pushing the charging undead back with the forces of nature and claws and wiping out the unit facing Vimack's squadron.
The trebuchets adjust, and focus upon the druids, lobbing their payload at them. The boulders impact around them, killing most of heir group. The lead druid maintains her concentration despite the screams and crashes, but the moment she opens her eyes, and sees she is the last one alive, her courage breaks and she attempts to flee the battlefield.
The Treants crash through the remaining enemy vanguard and the bear fighters clean up the remaining hounds that attacked Ronpip's horsemen among the horde of zombies. One Treant even pulls a large rock from the lake nearby and chucks it into the enemy. While the defense are being worn down by the zombie hordes, the enemy high elven archers finally take their action and fire upon the vanguard with no head for their own zombie units. Their arrows, despite being a large volley, are deadly accurate and pin down the defensive units.
Vimack is an unstoppable machine, tearing through individuals like they are nothing but training dummies, and giving his squadron increased moral and hype, and they follow through with as much energy as they can to match Vimack's seemingly endless rage and lightning.
Ronpip leads the charge on the otherside, using his horsemen to pin the war hounds and war champions from their flank by encroaching them like a whirlpool of blades and horses, whittling them away as they box them into death. Antilean rushes to Ronpip's side, helping pick off targets with Dragoon and healing Ronpip with a needle of healing liquids. Vimack continues to charge, despite the volleys of arrows, uncaring of the damage he is taking, but does not notice his unit is also taking some hits and dying to the barrage. Despite, Vimack gives another doubled down war cry, bringing attention to himself to get his units to charge with him into the enemy elven army headlong.
Priestess Yurreina Paramoure attempts to take control of Ronpip, but Ronpip's natural resistance to magic prevents her from taking his mind. Bothered, she attempts to target him directly, which catches Ronpip's attention. Ronpip warns Antilean that magic will not work with her, flips her the bird, and charges directly into her. Ronpip's sword hand waivers and tingles, but he strikes true, using the distance of his lance to maintain distance. He strikes her once with a charge and strikes her again with a thrust, which narrowly misses as Yurreina parries it away but with Ronpip's knowledge of fighting and the Tool of War's influence, rears the horse around to ensure the strike finds its purchase. Antilean, from a distance, assists Ronpip and takes shots at Yurreina between Ronpip's strikes, blasting portions of her armor off.
The enemy elven army attempt to barracade againt the horemen and Vimack. The horsemen charge with reckless abandon, weakening the wall as Vimack charges in with the same force as four more horses concentrated into a single being.
But, as soon as Vimack breaks into the army, magic drives itself into his mind and heart, and lost in his rage, he falls prey to mind control. Suddenly, a once inspiring ally has become a most fearsome foe, as Vimack turns on his own men without concern or notice.
Yurreina attempts to dismount and strike Ronpip, but she is still shellshocked and her body does not respond as quickly as she would like and she misses terribly. Her anger only rises. A strange sound comes from the sky, but none of the party notices anything strange.
Vimack hears a command in his own mind to attack his comrades; the sensation is foreign enough that Vimack, while not able to stop his action, is able to hold back enough from killing his own comrades. In realization, Vimack frees his mind from control and focuses on Elwin Petyra, the enemy elven leader and the one who tried to force Vimack to fight his own allies.
Ronpip shifts his lance into a great sword once more, and prepares a might swing the sunder the hammer from Yurreina's arms. Ronpip feints a lance thrust, but instead leaps from his mount and throws off his shield, and comes down swinging hard upon Yurreina. She attempts to block in reaction and keep her weapon in hand. Blinding white-blue sparks emit between the bite of the great sword and the warhammer, slicing it in half. The Tool of War feels stronger in Ronpip's hand, as though it had been rejuvenated in an eldritch way. Ronpip takes the opportunity from his battle high to make a second attack. Yurreina is taking aback that she quick steps back in retreat, but Ronpip rallies himself and continues to put pressure upon her, striking twice more, cutting through her armor and seeming slicing straight through the armor's enchatment. Antilean and Dragoon continue to follow up with shots between Ronpip's attacks, continuing to pick off chunks of her armor as Ronpip slices into the openings. She begins to puke blood as her body is beginning to give out.
Vimack's group is winded from chasing Vimack and formerly fighting zombies, and are starting to falter. Some of the archers fire at Vimack with deadly accuracy, noticing that their leader's control has been broken from him.
Critical Wound! One strikes straight into Vimack's arm and causes him to drop one of this swords from its force, his arm damaged to the point of unable to wield a weapon.
Petyra attempts to cast Hold Person upon him, and Vimack manages to rip the arcane chains from the Weave from the ground and prevents himself from being held down by magic.
Yurreina staggers, holding a hold in her stomach, and begins to chant a divine incantation. A halo of red light comes over her as her chanting reaches a crescendo. And the sound of a whistling object from the sky goes from a whisper to a scream and impacts directly upon Yurreina with the force of a trebuchet payload. But, Antilean and Ronpip do not see a large stone payload, and instead see a shell of metal, from which four metal automatons step out from. From the sky, an airship comes out from the cloud line, and Ronpip recognizes it as the Thumbleville Airbrigade bombarding the landscape with artillery from the sky. The Automatons are dropped straight on top of enemy armies, who then proceed to assist in the defense of Vasaaros.
A rope comes down from the sky near Ronpip, and greets Ronpip upon the battlefield. More gnomes drop down from the skyships above. Petyra is caught aghast and confused and angry and disappointed and frightened. He then spots Vimack making his way directly to him and all of his emotions conspire into a single primal fear for his own life. Vimack contemplates taking him on directly, but realizes he has an item that has the chance to end the fight sooner than if he were to attack head on with one arm and heavily wounded trying to reach Petyra. He pulls out The Talisman of Pure Good and invokes its spell towards him. A fissure to hell opens up, and hellfire chains rip through to pierce through him. In pain and shock, he turns into mist and tries to escape. But in pure irony, more chains explode from the fissure, enrapture the mist and drag it into the fissure, straight to the hells. The fissure closes and all thats left is a sliver of melted snow and the stench of brimstone that disappears along the wind. Petyra is gone, taken to the hells for whatever torturous unlife awaits him. The rest of the enemy elves begin to falter, seeing their leader has fallen and others seeing their comrades die to metal humanoids who do not tire and do not fear and do not have morals, they drop their weapons and flee. War champions of Yurreina are shot down with mirad of bolts, the dogs are put down to enternal sleep.
Vimack picks up his swords, sheathing one to pick his sundered one with his good hand. Antilean celebrated the end of the battle with gunshots into the air. Ronpip takes a trophy of Yurreina's head, or what is left of it from the impact.
And the party returns to the city with the rest of their new found comrades...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: A Blade Left Sundered
item.description:
Ronpip has discovered, after the mirror fiasco in the strange Drow cave, his sword had disappeared overnight.
Ronpip has questioned multiple people where it might have gone, but has gotten no answers. He is suspicious of everyone.
The sword was, in fact, not stolen.
Instinctually, Ronpip grasps for his sword, and it has popped into his hands from nothing. This is a shocking revelation! What more could it do?
The sword takes any shae that Ronpip desires; truly any tool of war he needs.
The sword can be thrown and allow Ronpip to teleport to it, a strange sensation but useful in battle.
The sword speaks to Ronpip and provides a ritual to directly interact with it. Perhaps it has answers.
The Tool of War is not in the sword; it is the sword.
The Tool of War has been in such a form longer than it could properly describe.
The Tool of War describes that it has been many things, but does not elaborate.
The Tool of War does not know why it has arrived to Ronpip's hands.
The Tool of War does not know why, in its magical space, it is chained, only that it is what it is, and it is a weapon.
The Tool of War is being held back.
The sword hungers for power. But... why?
When facing Yurreina, the sword was shaking. Was it fear? Anticipation? The Tool of War requests another fight against the weapon she brandished, but to what end?
Finally facing off against Yurreina, the sword cut through the anti-magic maul Yurreina held, and transformed. It absorbed its power and become more powerful!
What else could it consume/sunder to gain more power?
The sword may be from the other timeline, but Ronpip should ask the blacksmith he originally received it from.
The Blacksmith does not recognize the sword, nor knows of its origin. He unfortunately has no answers.

item.title: Draconian Experiments
item.description:
Vimack has purchased a strange stone egg from a seedy merchant. Surely, he was scammed...
What could possible be the origin of this egg? Is it even a creature's egg? But... from where?
The egg has reacted to Vimack in some way, but has not hatched. Perhaps more time is needed?
The egg has hatched, and a strange wyvern like creature has been born!
She is growing exceedingly fast for something only recently born. It hasn't even been a month and she is already a size Ronpip could ride upon.
The wyvern creature is some how able to cast something like Magic Missile as a breathe weapon. A strange ability, but what else could it do?
The party has searched a library in Massarnae, but no answers could be derived from it.
Hysseld has mentioned that the arcane wyvern has a strange stench of magic about it, and is ugly to bare looking at.
Perhaps she is not natural of origin, as other dragon associated creatures seem to find the arcane wyvern distressing to look at. Vimack would need to seek someone with magical animal knowledge as their specialty to perhaps find more answers.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Fair Day Marketing
item.description:
A failed marriage, a failed mercantile venture, and failed buyers to a product that is not selling its worth in gold. Maybe its just ahead of its time...
The ex wife has been met with again. She wishes Antilean a good luck on his journey, but to come back, if not at least for the kids.
Antilean still thinks success will bring his ex wife around to understanding his passion. He just needs to prove it.
The emperor of Vasaaros has taken interest in Antilean's firearms. Perhaps there is a deal to be struck!
Antilean still has friendly contacts out there, maybe one of them can help get his business going...
Antilean re-met Haggle who is still in good measure with Antilean in Phocellis. He could be a potential Seller if Antilean can get him something to sell.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Find the Facets of Virtue
item.description:
Vadathaus Horreneth revealed that his people will attain the Facets of Virtue, a mysterious relic of some great power.
Hysseld has told the party what the Facets of Virtue are, describing them as powerful gem stones. Unfortunately, he does not know their direct locations.
Facet of Fire; Location Unknown...
Facet of Water; Location Unknown...
By completing the Trials of Water with Lorellai against her parents, the party has obtained a relic. The First Tear, which appears to be one of the Facets that the party was looking for.
Facet of Metal; Location Unknown...
Facet of Wind; Location Unknown...
Facet of Wood; Location Unknown...
item.guid: Campaign/00 Parties/03 Quests/Active/Find the Facets of Virtue.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Home Coming
item.description: It has been an extended amount of time since Ronpip and Vimack have been to Thimbleville. With the appearance of functional airships, perhaps its time to return and see how much the city has grown in their absence...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Trail of Mountains
item.description:
Vimack was dropped off at the gnome village of Thimbleville, raised to be the brother of Ronpip. But he is not a gnome, nor do the gnomes know much about the history or culture of Goliaths.
Vimack has met a strange woman, Dorizoul, whose companions recognize him as a giant. Perhaps she knows more than she lets on...
Dorizoul was met again on Lover's Bridge in Vasaaros, and has led him to a Giant's Waystone that lies deep within the waters of the canal. However, she has disappeared before he could get another question...
Perhaps along his travels around the world, Vimack will come upon more signs left behind by the Goliaths or Giant-kind...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Dragon's Head Manor
item.description:
Several Hundred Gold has been given to Yohan Sheppard in Dragon's Head to build a manor for the party. Said manor is being built over where the party discovered the Mirror Wall Made of Time Crystal in the Mysterious Cave.
Blueprints for the Manor include:

First Floor
One Entry Foyer
One Large Greeting Area
Two Sitting Rooms
One Kitchen Area
One Common Dining Area
Second Floor
6 personal bedrooms with closets
One Large Library Area
One Common Area
One Sitting Rooms
Balcony
Bridge to Extension
Third Floor
Large Attic Area
Basement
Cellar and Storage Area
Direct Access to the Mirror Wall Made of Time Crystal
Extension
Workshop Area
Training Area
item.guid: Campaign/00 Parties/04 Service Request/In-Progress/Dragon's Head Manor.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Evan's Letter to his Family
item.description: I would like to let my the the House of Escense know that the know that their son, evan, is currently in Massarnae but will leaving on a a short journey joining a caravan to establish a township of some kind in, Which way is this forest going to be? In some area North of Massarnae, if you need, if you need a, if you need some confirmation that it is being sent from their son, I have my signet ring. I am happy to stamp a wax seal, if need be. I think that’s all I would like to tell them.
item.guid: Campaign/00 Parties/05 Letters/Delivered/Evan's Letter to his Family.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: House Escence's Reply
item.description:
Dearest Evan, our son.
We have received your letter for our house, and we are happy to know you are safe. As many of your letters through the arcadian courier service have surmised, we are happy to see that there were less paper used since your last letter, though it still translates as directions and not a personal recount. Your mother had to be explained the letter and humbly asks you handwrite your letters, though I told her of your typical preferal of utilizing pre-established services.
My son, when you get this letter, I implore you; return to Visaros at your earliest leisure. I fear the other houses are growing impatient while the seat of the emperor remains empty. Already, House Ledd has been attacked, and your good friend, Zepplin, has been in the infirmary since the day this letter was sent. I fear it was the work of another House, and so long as they fight, there will be no order within the Empire. The direness of the events here in the capital is so great, even your… teacher… has returned. Please, come home, son...
Please, return safely… George Diorissimo Escence
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: The Final Written Words of Vydimal
item.description:
found in the Tome of Endless Lore
Dear Read(Evan Escence), Unfortunately, I've had to given up this book. The Winter has called for me, and I cannot abandon The Call, so I cannot fulfill this book. Fidchelle will know this act and that I cannot continue to scribe into this book. And if I do not die with this book, maybe this book can be passed down to another chosen one, and more can scribed into this book. Keep it safe, and maybe you won't have to see this message... and maybe I can see Hysseld again...
item.guid: Campaign/00 Parties/05 Letters/Delivered/The Final Written Words of Vydimal.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Facets of Virtue
item.description:
Rumoured stones of incredible power, these crystals have been lost to the world for some time. Each one represents a major element that holds the material plane together, and follows a certain philosophy behind each element, which allegedly alters how the element can be used or behaves.

Fire for Wisdom (Good) or Ash for Naivety (Evil)
Water for Benevolence (Good) or Frost of Malevolence (Evil)
Earth for Loyalty (Good) or Sand for Betrayal (Evil)
Wood for Order (Law) or or Brambles for Disorder (Chaos)
Metal for Righteousness (Law) or Rust for Insidious (Chaos)
However, the reality of the existence of the stones is nothing more than a fable at best...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Ritual of Calm
item.description: Ritual performed by a Storm Herald to mark a person as one with the storm. Although it contains much shamanistic ritualism, there is no real magic behind it No enchantment or manipulation of the weave in anyway, bordering the line near theatrics. It is simply symbolic and meant to inspire the individual to do more than they would perhaps have done on their own.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Style
item.description:
A potential Disease spread by the nobles in which they feel compelled dress in "high fashion" clothes and accessories, and are compelled to contort their bodies to the full flexibility of human anatomy and questionable positions that affects their everyday physical and social activities.
Contagious?
Patient Zero: Evan Escence
Other Possible Carriers:

George Diorissimo Escence - Alive/ Location: Vasaaros of Arcaedia
Ed Sher'ran - Alive/ Location: Unknown
Brand Diodah Urie - Deceased
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: The Pilgrimage of Giants
item.description:
Based on older stories passed down by word of mouth before the first books could be written, the Pilgrimage was the path the Giants, and thusly the Goliath peoples, took upon searching for their place in the Ordning, the Order of Ranking according to the All-Father of Giants. The journey itself was a metaphor about "climbing the mountain" or so many scholars and philosophers believe. No actual path can seemingly be surmised between any point, way marks being scattered among various areas across the known continents, and stories of success and failure to complete the trials set out by the pilgrimage varying wildly between those who have given up and those who claimed success.
What continuity does exist is that, a person seeking to start the pilgrimage must start at the "lowest low" often described as the "river carved in the valley". And then a progression of slowly increasing, uphill trials, akin to an ant climbing to the peak of the highest mountain. Allegedly, the completion of the trials allows safe passage towards the Eye of Kapheira, the ever-tempest that sends endlessly spiraling winds across the known continents, which would be normally impossible to reach by boat or magically by air.
It would seem either the journey was not meant for many, or the few that reached their stopping point simply found their place and accepted it, as there has been no report of anyone ever reaching the Eye of Kapheria and surviving. But, if passage to the Eye of Kapheira marks the end of the journey, then the unreachable high tower that breaches the clouds must be related to the Giants in some way... It is, of course, speculation from a safe distance at best.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Time Spider
item.description:
Mysterious motif of a spider associated with time. Speculated to be associated with the Drow do to minor clues of Drow activity near such motifs.
However, not much more is known, as no one has ventured into the Underdark and returned alive or sane, and none from the Underdark have come to greet us, by hand or sword...
The last known time the Drow have ever surfaced was a time only the surfave elves would have recorded, and they guard their secrets of history from most.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Tullum Pugna Nula
item.description:
"Tullum Pugna Nula" is a set of old laws started by old Arcaedian founders as a way to settle problematic arguments where words were not proving to be enough. The old law states, roughly, "If by one phase of the moon, no agreement can come between two houses of noble blood, that a trial by combat may settle the deal, so long as both parties agree to it. The challenger chooses the location, the challenged chooses the terms. And to the death, may the one standing be right in his ways."
Being that of old law, it remains in obscurity and diplomatic practices have long since evolved to bring about a better send of justice for all parties associated in heavy debate. However, if the length of time has passed and no resolution has been met in the time allotted, an Arcaedian noble could invoke this law as a challenge, to either eliminate his competition or to weaken them by forcing them to refuse the challenge.
Scholars and philosophers have long considered if this really solved anything, but as one Arcaedian writer put it during one of the more dire invasions upon Vasaaros, "History is often written by the victors..."
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Akadi
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Ah-kah-dee"

Akadi was both the whispering wind and the turbulent tempest, sweet and moist at times while bitter and cold at others, her form changing with the seasons. In religious depictions she was often portrayed as a giant, blue, translucent woman with huge feathery wings that trailed away into the clouds. The Lady of the Winds was revered in both male and female aspects in different parts of Arcaedia , and the distinction between these representations made no difference to her faithful.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Amaunator
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Ah-maw-nay-tor"

Amaunator's avatar, whose skin shed golden light, looked like a lanky, silver-white haired, and short man with a white tenday growth of beard clad in a long, flowing, black or purple gown with silver or gold trims, the uniform of a magistrate. He always equipped himself with two tools: a scepter and a legal tome in either hand. The former was the scepter of the eternal sun, which doubled as his melee-weapon.
Amaunator preached that people needed to follow laws to the letter. The reason for this was the belief that laws were the foundation on which any society was built on and disrespecting law would inevitably cause the collapse of any society. The same adherence was also extended to traditions.
The Yellow God's also taught that people had to familiarize themselves with law to get an understanding how to act in a proper manner that saved them from getting punished. He also wanted people to be organized individuals who met their commitments and were always on time.
His message also extended to hierarchies mortals made for themselves. The Keeper of the Eternal Sun told his followers to adhere to their superiors. The idea behind it was that faithful service would yield them rewards while failure to do so punishment. That said, people were told to keep tabs on their superiors' decisions. This was to increase the number of precedents to draw from and help to standardize rulings and with it the relevance of Amaunator's message.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Angharradh
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Ahn-ghar-rahd" !


Elven goddess associated with the moon. Her worship was of an ancient age, though many statues of her still exist in carved moonstone in High Elven cities. It is said that she represents the three spirits of night: the hidden lights, the secrets of shadow, and the hope of the new dawn.
To the high elves, she is the revealer of secrets, especially of that which is hidden in the night. Many high elves star gazers have charted millions of stars to find answers, or seek a path to something perhaps greater than themselves.
She is also one to hide that which should not be seen; an example to live by to the greatest hunter, stalker, and assassin. Silence in shadows, grace in the night, and perfection in the hunt.
Finally, in some irony as she is a goddess of the moon, she is also one of fortuitous ends. The dawn is a new day, and with her coming, another shall follow. Though sometimes she hides herself, she remains watching overall all from the darkness sky until the sun rises anew.

So far, the party has only found one instance of the Elven Goddess, in the form a moonstone statue in the city of Mira Esmirelda. Ronpip had regarded the statue and appraised it on the spot, determining it to be of exceptional value. He had wondered why the people would leave a statue of high worth in a fetid swamp...¹
The party has not been taken notice by the Goddess.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Azuth
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Azuth's avatar was usually 10 feet (3 meters) tall, and he was generally depicted as a white-haired, bearded, vigorous old man garbed in gray silk robes (and never wearing a hat).
He could, however, shapechange at will and often appeared as a 20 feet (6.1 meters) tall pyramid shape with no apparent eyes or mouths covered in glittering, pulsing lights.
As the Lord of Spells, a major duty of Azuth's was to monitor the casting of Epic Magic, and curb its usage amidst non-mortals & extraplanars, especially when this was done heedlessly.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Chauntea
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Chauntea, when in her home realms, manifested with the appearance of a giant beautiful human woman. The Earthmother had long shiny white hair, gathered in a long braid she wrapped around her head. The length of her braid suggested the woman's great age. She had pleasant features and brown skin. Chauntea's body was lean but toned, muscled similarly to a farmer's body, shaped by hard work. She carried herself with strength and femininity. If one was to forget that they observed a deity, they could assume the beautiful woman in front of them was in her middle-age. Some described her appearance as "a rose in full bloom."
Chauntea was seen by Faerûnians as a critical aspect of the assumed cycle of life. Private land owners and destitute farmers (perhaps as a consequence of an unproductive harvest) visited the clerics of Chauntea for any divine suggestions for aiding the harvest. If at any time plague or drought struck the crops, farmers looked to Chauntea, since they hoped she would save the harvest, due to her love of nature. Though she had a diverse collection of followers, Chauntea was fanatically worshiped by peasants, servants, druids, gardeners, and any others who earned pay from working on farmland. Her clergy were known for ministering in rural communities, and for their willingness to work in the community's fields next to the local farmers.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Deneir
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Deneir was portrayed in religious depictions as an old, balding sage with a huge, flaring beard. Sometimes his eyes were a vibrant violet with triangular pupils, at others a brilliant ice blue, and at others still they were blazing balls of blue fire, but they were always peculiar in some way. He was always shown holding a quill and with some form of parchment, either carrying or writing in a book or scroll.
Deneir most often appeared as he was depicted, with a white beard and intense blue or violet eyes, usually carrying quill pens, scrolls, and tomes. He sometimes, however, appeared younger, especially when in disguise. His voluminous robes were covered in symbols and glyphs that initiated random effects on those who touched them, ranging in effect from standard glyph or symbol spells, miscellaneous spell effects, or just bizarre happenings. The symbols seemed to serve as some sort of code to remind him of specific facts and events.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Eldath
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Eldath normally appeared in a 10 ft (3 m) tall female form, but the details varied. Depictions in religious art and known appearances had her as a human, wild elf, sea elf, dryad, and nereid. She was tall, thin, graceful, beautiful, and her form was always translucent enough to be seen through at all times. Sometimes she was said to have dark hair while at others her hair was colorless like water, and seemed more like spun glass or flowing ice; as a dryad or wild elf, her hair was blue and green. Her eyes were a deep shade of green.
Eldathyns were organized into a simplistic hierarchy, where priests reported to a local high priest responsible for a realm or larger region. Most followers dwelt in quiet forest communities with open-air sacred places of worship or in woodside cottages, far from the baseness of city life; both often containing pools of placid water in unspoiled areas. They rarely ever engaged in open confrontation and always acted subtly and peacefully.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Fidchelle the Aspect of Lore
item.description:
Fidchell appears to be a masked humanoid inset into an ornate lotus flower that balances upon a point. He has four discs in the shape of eyes that hover around him. His mask is also beset with eyes and has four spokes like a fan upon its face, also inladen with eyes. His arms are often kept in a prayer or meditation position. Despite being known as the aspect of knowledge, the proper translation is the Aspect of Lore. He is often regarded for his wisdom gained from the knowledge and memory of history through time.
Fidchell often takes no action, with or against his siblings. He only observes, and that often leaves his siblings in anger with him. However, he is one of the eldest aspects, being the one who observes all of time.
The ancient followers of Fidchell did the same, observe and record. They were known to have vast libraries filled with the knowledge they acquired from others. They were skilled in many things, especially in language and writing. On top of having an extensive background history on the ancient races, they also seemed to follow a prophetic doctrine that was claimed to have been handed down to them by Fidchell himself. However, the true translation of this prophecy seems to have been lost, either buried within the deep knowledge and recordings of his followers, or it had been lost through time.
Though Fidchell has offered no direct assistance, his followers have made artifacts in an attempt to emulate his power and provide ease to their recordings.
Provides the Tome of Endless Lore to his followers to continue to endlessly gather information and history.
item.guid: Campaign/02 Deities/Fidchelle the Aspect of Lore.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Gond
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Avatars of Gond took several forms, including that of a brawny, red-hued smith, a short, slight man with straw-blond hair, or a gnome. No matter his form, Gond had a forge-scarred face with dark (but nonetheless sharp and bright) eyes and a constantly attentive and inquisitive expression. He wore ordinary leathers under his scorched smith smock, though he could also summon a set of glassteel plate armor over himself (hovering close to his body piece by piece rather than actually encasing him) at will.
Gond's manifestations included a forge hammer wrapped with wisps of black smoke, or striking eyes set within dark clouds with the ringing sounds of hammers on anvils.
While Gond was wholly devoted to his mortal followers, he remained too busy at times to answer their prayers in a timely manner. While the Wonderbringer directed them to promote invention and new ideas, he was not opposed to his followers accumulating significant personal wealth in the process. To many this was seen as an appropriate means for Gondar priests to demonstrate their worthiness of his blessing.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Gwaeron Windstrom
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Gwaeron always appeared as a 6.5 feet (2 meters) or 10 feet (3 meters) tall human male, robust and incredibly muscular despite his age. His hair was long and white, with a mane and beard that flowed and whipped in the wind, billowing even in the absence of a breeze (though this was possible because he was constantly wind walking and so created a breeze). He always wore clothing suitable for wilderness travel, but never anything above his waist. He was normally silent, and when he did speak it was in terse sentences with little physical sign of emotion.
Few aside from Northern rangers prayed to Gwaeron or even knew of his faith, and even amongst his followers he was not exactly venerated. Rather, the active rangers of the north held Gwaeron in high esteem, praying to him because he represented their work. His faith could be considered one of emulation, his folowers viewing him as one of their own and thus understanding of their needs. He was seen as the master ranger and perfect tracker, as well as an unrivaled animal handler and dedicated foe of rapacious monsters like orcs and trolls.
Just as Gwaeron sometimes acted as Mielikki's emissary among the divine, Gwaeron was also her proxy among mortals in his role as the Mouth of Mielikki. Even though most human rangers favored Mielikki, they considered her too wild, primal, enigmatic and holy to be directly petitioned in most situations. Instead they prayed to Gwaeron, who they believed would carry their words to the goddess by tracking her to whatever forest she was hiding in and who would communicate with them on her behalf where direct speech was needed.
Aside from them, Gwaeron was also venerated by Northern trackers in general, whether their quarry was wild game or outlaws. For example, he might be prayed to by human sailors attempting to find another vessel or those hunting for pirates.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Helm
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Helm always appeared as a 14​ to ​20 feet (4.3​ to ​6.1 meters) tall man in plate mail armor, his face concealed by his helm.
A very old deity, Helm was the eternal sentry and was always seen wearing a full suit of armor that represented the weight of his heavy responsibility. Yet Helm always got the job at hand done without complaint. The people of the Realms widely admired these qualities in what they saw as a humble and reassuring god.
Helm was particularly fond of children, and often forgave their minor transgressions.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Ilmater
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


In avatar form, Ilmater appeared as a short man with a burly build and wearing only a breechcloth, with a plain but kind and comforting face, balding head, and a hairy body. But this body bore the marks of mutilation and torture on the rack, covered with open cuts, closed scars, burns, and a range of other wounds. Ilmater's joints were broken, his limbs were ravaged, and his hands were smashed yet still functional. Moving caused him a great deal of pain as he dragged himself around. No matter how much his avatar healed, it still showed these terrible wounds.
Those who were oppressed, sick, lame, or poor were likely to be worshipers of Ilmater, and people who had been injured or were otherwise suffering would often call upon him for aid. His faith was popular among the poor in big cities, and with serfs and slaves, as well as merchants, thieves, and a few guards. Although people of any alignment could worship Ilmater, he was largely followed by folk of a lawful and good bent, especially among his own clergy.
Ilmater's clergy numbered clerics, paladins, and monks. They were organized into the Church of Ilmater, with many affiliated knightly and monastic orders.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Innis the Aspect of Ambition
item.description:
Innis is described as an angelic priestess who bears the wheel of fate behind them. The “wheel” has sixed bladed spokes that protrude past the wheel itself, and the entire accessory is covered in eyes. She bares a complete halo, encircled with eyes, and her robe is also decorated with eyes. She wields two massive blades of light, both of which hover past her hands. She is coy, influential, and oftentimes manipulative. She is goal oriented, and will stop at nothing to obtain what she desires.
The ancient followers of Innis were often misguided in their own goals. She brought with her justification for anyone’s desires, good or bad. She was the double edged sword, where someone’s good intention often lead to destruction, or someone’s ill will upon another lead to their uprising. She is also often the starter of many wars among the various races. Those who worshipped her could be any part of the extreme; thusly, no temple or location of general worship of her is usually found in one place.
Being one to influence others to seek out their own interests, Innis has shared some of her gifts to the mortal realm, all leading to both utopia and cataclysm throughout written and unwritten histories.
One such item is the Solitaire of Inspiration.
item.guid: Campaign/02 Deities/Innis the Aspect of Ambition.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Jergal
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Jergal was frequently depicted as a member of an ancient alien race that resembled a cross between a humanoid and a praying mantis. He was a wizened and insubstantial creature, mummy-like in appearance with gray, tightly taut skin. His elongated skull hosted bulbous, yellow eyes devoid of life and insectoid mandibles, as well as a nose and ears barely distinguishable from the rest of his head.
Jergal's lengthy, claw-like hands and forearms were covered by a pair of white gloves. Most of his form was also covered, hidden behind a gray, shadow-filled cloak that seemed to absorb the very atmosphere around it and moved as if blown in a wind, even if none was present. Its outer surface was a gate to the Negative Energy plane. In his clutches was a quill with fresh ink and a thick scroll covered in an intricate and incomprehensible script.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Lathander
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"
|l

During his numerous visits to the Great Mother's Garden, Lathander appeared as a giant of a man, to match the size of his lover, Chauntea. His visage radiated bright shine of the morning sun and his hair burned with flaming orange-red fire. Lathander appeared as a handsome young slender muscled human man. His preferred clothes were a set of colorful robes of reds, pinks, and yellows. A red and golden sash embraced the god's waist. He wore golden sandals and left scorch marks everywhere his feet touched the ground. Lathander often floated and liked to materialize in a glorious spectacle of dawn sun beams. His radiant face darkened akin to solar eclipse when the god was angered or upset.
All of Lathander's clergy respected art, liberty, nature, and culture; promoted betterment of oneself; and strove to bring hope to their followers and others. Many of these followers worked in various creative arts. They were intolerant of evil, especially undead and inaction that caused evil to prosper. Most ceremonies of Lathander were held at dawn and actions and contracts agreed to at sunrise were said to be blessed by him. Funerals, among his followers, were held at dusk, and followed by a wake that lasted until dawn.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Lliira
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Lliira initially manifested as brightly whirling lights and smoke in the middle of the air before a young woman danced out from the cloud. This 9 feet (2.7 meters) lady was sensuous and shapely, laughing and dancing through the air without concern for dignity or pride. She had eyes of pure blue, long, golden hair (sometimes streaked with silver or odd pastels of blue, pink, green, or lilac), and wore a tight-fitting body suit under a series of thin, translucent robes which artfully twirled and draped as she moved. A sparkling wake of winking lights trailed behind her as she danced, flashing at least 60 feet (18 meters) behind her and longer if she so desired.
Both the specialty priests and clerics of Lliira were known distinguished by the title of "Joydancer." Her clergy were renowned throughout Arcaedia for their easy going and good-hearted nature, making them some of the most popular clerics in the continent.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Mielikki
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Mielikki's preferred avatar was the Supreme Ranger, where she appeared as a tall woman of robust and shapely build and lithe grace. She moved with the spring of a leaping buck and the ease of a prowling panther. Her russet-colored hair was long and unbound so it hung around her shoulders and down her back, while her eyes were large and brown, and deep like pools. Her clothes were dull green and brown in color and she wore the leather armor commonly used by rangers.
She was venerated by woodsmen among the humans, elves (especially wood elves), and half-elves, as well as by dryads, hamadryads, and treants, and by forest creatures with no common gods of their own. Common folk appealed to her when children were lost in the forest, so she might protect and guide them. Woodcutters left simple shrines to her in thanks for their safety and for the wood they'd taken, and such shrines marked the limits of future hunting and logging. Otherwise, the Lady of the Forest was little talked about, except in peaceful woodland settings.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Milil
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Milil appeared as a young, charismatic 10 feet (3 meters) tall male with shoulder-length golden hair, indistinguishable as either human or elf. His clean, handsome good looks were exceeded by hauntingly beautiful voice. He dressed in the bright, elegantly patterned clothes of a troubadour accented with gold jewelry and other eye-catching decorations.
He was predominantly worshiped by human, elf, and half-elf bards but attracted other musically inclined individuals such as troubadours and poets. The faith of Milil was an organized group that attracted attractive, sensual, and musically inclined followers. In addition to their affinity with song and musical instruments, they tended to appreciate good food and wine, and the beauty found in both nature and civilized society. The church was composed primarily of clerics, but also included bards, mystics, and spellsingers.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Mystra
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


The only known description of the mortal that became Mystra was of a "beautiful peasant girl" who was just beginning her studies of the Art.
As a goddess, Mystra could shape change at will and mortals who saw her reported she changed constantly. Others described her appearing in a form resembling a multicolored will-o'-wisp. When Mystra revealed herself to Midnight just before the gods were forced to walk the land of Toril, she was at first just a dark figure surrounded by an aura of blue-white light. As she created the pendant that held some of her power, the glow revealed the face of a "beautiful, willful young woman, with hints of a long-borne pain." Mystra's avatar at the time was a slim, young girl named Caitlan Moonsong who had a graceful bearing, large, dark eyes and short-cropped blond hair. Caitlan went barefoot and wore plain ankle-length robes of a dark hue. When possessed by Mystra, she appeared taller and her hair moved as if it were alive.
This incarnation of the Mother of All Magic was quite the opposite of her predecessor, Mystryl. Whereas Mystryl was quixotic and quick to change, Mystra was said to be a manifestation of the Cosmic Balance—maintaining order in the world of magic by correcting great inequalities if things went askew. Indeed, in the wake of the Fall of Netheril, one of her first acts as the Lady of Spells was to ban the use of all magic greater than ninth level. Among sages and historians this was known as Mystra's Ban. She was not as concerned with the ethics of Good versus Evil as long as the laws of magic were upheld.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Oghma
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Although he was seldom sighted and was depicted in many different forms, Oghma's avatar most often appeared as a handsome, dark-skinned man in bright, resplendent, and stylish clothes and ornate armor more appropriate to a fantastic stage play than anywhere else. Typically, his outfit included a tabard with projecting, ornamented shoulder plates; a cummerbund with an exquisitely beautiful scene painted on its medallion-shaped buckle; and open-meshwork boots with long pointed toes that curled around and were tipped with dangling crystal teardrops that nearly touched the toes.
The Lord of Knowledge had the distinction of being revered by beings of every race, every stratum of society, and every philosophy and moral alignment.Unlike most neutral gods, his clerics could be of any alignment including neutral. All folk who valued, preserved, shared, sought, created, or uncovered knowledge and learning were perforce followers of Oghmaand anyone looking for information, especially if it was lost or concealed, would say a prayer to the Binder and beseech him for a blessing. Those who worshiped Oghma included artists, artisans, bards, cartographers, clerks, inventors, librarians, loremasters, sages, scholars, scribes, smiths, and wizards. Archivists and truenamers might pray to him as well. Oghma was also among the deities of knowledge favored by the Fraternity of Order in the planes.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Red Knight
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


The Red Knight always appeared in blood-red plate mail, her presence commanding attention and respect. Her long braids of dark hair streamed out behind her while her eyes gleamed like ruby stars.
The Red Knight was worshiped by generals, tacticians, lawful-minded warriors and paladins alike. Her symbol was a red knight chess piece with stars for eyes.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Savras
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


He was portrayed as a man with a crystalline face, clear to all who saw him. His statements were clear, concise, and rarely what the listener wished to hear. Savras' symbol was a monstrous eye, or a crystal ball filled with eyes.
Savras' main duty was to monitor the casting of Epic Magic, and curb its usage amidst non-mortals & extraplanars, especially when this was done heedlessly.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Selûne
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


In both her avatars and her religious artwork, Selûne appeared in many forms, like the phases of the moon. One was a dusky-skinned human woman with long limbs; perfect and exquisite beauty; wide, radiant, lime-green eyes; and long, ivory-hued hair that fell to her knees. Another was an ethereal young girl of slender frame, dark eyes, and dark hair, wearing diaphanous robes colored white or resembling dappled moonlight, which trailed her "moondust" or "moon motes". A third was a matronly middle-aged woman, plump yet fair and aging gracefully, with gray-streaked dark hair.
Like the cycles of the moon, Selûne had many and changing moods and natures. Her faithful, coming from many walks of life, viewed her in countless different ways, and she reflected this. Sometimes she was enthusiastic, vivacious, joyous, and majestic, given to action and dance. At other times, she was subdued, motherly, and almost poetic or tranquil and embracing. Then she was remote and weighed down by sadness at defeats and tragedies, even those that happened long, long ago. Finally, she could be aggressive and fierce, but cold, and with little mercy for her enemies. These shifting personalities made her versatile. Nevertheless, she was viewed as a calm power.
Nevertheless, at all times, Selûne was caring and accepting of most beings, and forgiving of most of her followers' faults. She was both ageless and ancient. She was quietly mystical and, as a being of chaos, well used to change. She had a serene and peaceful nature and was slow to anger; she would not fight if she could help it, but nor did she hold back if she must. She was fiercely protective when confronted by evil.
She was generous and freely bestowed gifts and blessings on mortals. She also made few demands of her followers. When beseeched by her clergy, she always responded.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Shar
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


In religious artwork, Shar was depicted as a darkly beautiful human woman with long raven-black hair and clad all in black, swirling attire. Her eyes were large and haunting, and were solid purple with pupils as black as coal and reflecting the void at the dawn of time, and when she smiled it was cold as night. When visiting mortals in dreams, her dark hair would move and swirl regardless of gravity or outside forces, such as wind.
An alternative image was that of a simple black sphere limned in rushing purple flames; these were typically magically animated.
In her old depictions, a force of destruction and darkness, the very existence of Shar was paradoxical but was the living embodiment of the void, the perfect nothing that existed before she was born. The emptiness that she originally reflected had itself been erased at the start of time, and she longed to return to the ancient calm of nonexistence. And so she would disrupt order, bring down established systems, and undo everything. By her very nature, Shar was defined by loss, the foolishness of hope, and life's inherent emptiness. She was a goddess of pains and wrongs kept hidden yet never forgotten, of concealed hatred and unnatural desires that lurked in one's heart, of nursed grudges and hungered-for revenge cultivated in secret for any slight or offense, however old and cold it was. She enjoyed concealing things and keeping secrets for their own sake, so they never saw the light of day.
In the current depictions of Shar through Arcaedia, she is still a Mistress of Night and Lady of Loss. She is still cold and secretive. But her destructive and sadistic nature has all but been rewritten so that her worship can continue in the conglomeration of Arcaedian deisms. She often prayed to hide grief or secrets the same as she hides in the darkness of night. Her temples are kept as dark, calming places to allow others to process their pains and grievances without disturbance or a spotlight upon them. As well, the Inquisitors have a sect that utilize Shar's tenants, and could be regarded as Dark Justiciars, repurposed to fit with the new times and realm.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Shaundakul
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Shaundakul appeared as a handsome man of regal bearing, standing somewhere between the normal but notably tall height of 6 feet (1.8 meters) to the incredible stature of 18 feet (5.5 meters). He was clad in the plain leather armor favored by most rangers as well as a dark, swirling cloak being constantly whipped about as if buffeted by the wind. Usually only his dark-haired head, his arms, and his massive sword could be seen clearly. Since his booted feet never quite touched the ground he walked in silence, but was constantly accompanied by the keening whistle of the wind.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Silvanus
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Silvanus had both an old and young avatar form that he was known to manifest in.
His old form was known as the Old Father. It took the form of an old, bearded human male face, either floating midair among trees or sprouting from the trunk of an especially large and old tree. The flesh of this form was always brown, gray, and fissured like old wood.
His young form was known as the Young Strider. This was a young, long-limbed humanoid male, with particularly long legs, dressed in a suit of armor made of leaves and wielding a wooden mallet. He most often assumed this form when a sacred grove was threatened or a circle of druids was attacked during their worship.
Another form he was known to manifest as was the Horned Hunter, an entity similar in appearance to his fellow Celtic god Cerunnos. This form was an always silent man with burning white eyes, sporting a set of stag antlers and shaggy brown fur that was almost bark-like. This form always appeared among the trees, often just to indicate something by a gesturing, nodding, or pointing before disappearing.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Sune
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


When Sune appeared she did so as a human female of unearthly beauty dressed in only a near-transparent gown of silk. She was known for her lustrous, impossibly long red hair, the color of which persisted regardless of any other permutations in her appearance, and which often assumed the appearance of flames. Aside from this, her physical manifestation would change from time to time. Her skin might be golden, mahogony, reddish, or ivory, and her eyes might be sky-blue, forest green, almond-shaped, or of darkest amber or honey. her eyes of shining emeralds, and ruby red plump lips. She occasionally wore ruby gemstones in her hair.
Sune was a benevolent goddess that abhorred the destruction of beauty. She thrived on the tenderest of emotions and truly loved and protected her followers, reserving her deepest love for the mortals who revered her. She was also one of the most vain entities in the cosmos, enjoying attention and sincere flattery while avoiding the horrific and boorish.
The sometimes whimsical Princess of Passion alternated between deep passion and casual flirtation with others. When she was truly interested in a person or god, she wholeheartedly believed in these deep-seated feelings, but though she was one of the most passionate beings in existence, her focus lasted only a short time (as long as the subject continued to be enticing) before she lost interest and moved on.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Talona
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Talona appeared as a gaunt, 10‑foot (3‑meter) human female with long, unkempt hair and reaching, elongated fingers. Her depictions in religious texts portrayed her as a withered crone with a scarred, tattooed face. The bodies of her avatars seemed like they had been beautiful and voluptuous at one point, but their frames and charms had been ravaged by the march of time, horrific diseases, and starvation. Even so, Talona's dancing movements were said to be alluring, and her lips were nonetheless inviting and gentle.
Talona was also sometimes depicted as a beautiful and innocent woman.
Her priests, known collectively as Talontar, typically wore ragged gray-green robes. Though they would wash these vestiments, they would never repair them. Older and high-ranking members of her priesthood tended to either ritually scar or tattoo their bodies all over. When embarking on a battle or dangerous adventure, a follower of Talona would often don armor of a black and purple hue that was adorned with a variety of spurs, horns, and spikes.
Her followers often sold various poisons, antidotes, and medicines. When not doing so they were known to travel, seeking out new diseases or afflictions while also spreading rumors about Talona in hopes of boosting her reputation.
Talontar devoted much of their lives to building up an immunity to various diseases and poisons, by means of both inoculation and magic. Because of this, they often treated those afflicted with disease or buried their bodies. They also tended to be hired by paranoid members of high society, such as wealthy merchants or rulers, to test their food for any poison.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Talos
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Tah-lohs"


Talos appeared as a broad-shouldered, bearded man with one good eye. He wore half-plate armor over black leather and black leather gloves. His empty eye socket was filled with whirling stars and covered with a dark eye patch.
Prior to his merged and tamed worship in Arcaedia, he was called upon by a different name; Kozah. Worshiped by Raiders, Ravagers, and Brigands, he was said to bless any who would see destruction wrought upon the world. But that was during a warring time, a time of chaos and atrocity. Now, he is merely the Stormlord, and one worshipped in Arcaedia as a master of sea side winds, and the leash holder to the Eye of Kapheira. He is the one you appeased to ensure safe journey along the waters of the Midling Sea.
His religious iconography is also often spotted upon Judges, especially those sent out to destroy targets of interest.

During their time in Massarnae, Ronpip sought out a temple, in which he could confess certain actions that he felt bad for. The priest, unsure of how to take Ronpip's awkward confession, offered him a blessing of Talos for which he could take solace behind.¹
The God has not taken any interest in any party member or their actions...
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Tempus
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Tempus appeared as a 12 feet (3.7 meters) tall human in battered and bloodied plate mail, his face hidden by a giant war helm, though his gaze remained a palpable force. His arms and legs remained bare (although he did wear gauntlets) and were crisscrossed by wounds oozing with his smoking, wine-red blood, yet he remained unaffected by these injuries
Tempus was a being of chaos, distributing his favor randomly. Such was the nature of war that he might side with one army one day and turn against them the next. He was not heartless, but exuberant, said to live only for excess, whether it be love for food, drink, hunting, or his greatest passion, battle.
Despite his fickleness and what others might think of him because of it, Tempus was also not treacherous. Indeed, he was honorable in battle, and would hate to betray a confidence. The chaotic god simply answered to his own warrior code, carving out his own path and letting none stand in his way. Rather than switching sides, it would be more accurate to say that the Lord of Battle's chaotic nature was on all sides equally, so long as each was committed to victory.
Tempus' orders to all combatants were simple and direct:

Be fearless
Never turn away from a fight.
Obey the rules of war.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Torm
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Torm could appear as a 12 feet (3.7 meters) tall man in ancient, helmless plate mail stained dusky purple. Sometimes his form was that of a blond, handsome young man, while at others he was an aging warrior with grey-white hair, though he often shapeshifted into a lion-headed man when entering combat. No matter his form, he seemed stern in voice and manner, with dauntless courage set in his square jaw and righteous light flashing from his striking, deep blue eyes.
The symbol of the Loyal Fury, a right-hand gauntlet held upright with palm forward, was known as the Hand Resolute among his followers. It symbolized not only that Torm was the good right hand of Tyr, representing the God of Justice's missing sword hand, but also the principle of forbearance, that the true and just had to pause and consider their actions first so as to ensure their intent would uphold the chivalric ideals Torm exemplified.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Tymora
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Commonly known as Lady Luck, Tymora shone upon those who took risks and blessed those who dealt harshly with the followers of Beshaba.
When Tymora appeared, which was rare, she liked to take a form of a fit female, with an impish nose and long flowing white hair with a capricious lock that periodically danced on her forehead. She usually materialized barefoot and wore a blue robe with silver trim. She liked to appear as a member of whatever race the observer belonged to, which meant that each person could simultaneously see her as a member of their own race.
When Tymora manifested as an avatar her voice could carry for more than a 100 miles. Any game based on chance would be won by ridiculously improbable odds if played within a hundred yards of her avatar. She was capable of sensing acts of good fortune as soon as they happened. Beings of her faith would also receive small magic resistance. She could also change between bird and human forms at will.
Tymora was immune to all illusions, charm spells, priest spells from numbers spheres, thought spheres, chaos spheres, law spheres, and time spheres. Any wild magic wizard spells cast near Tymora would twist and aid her or her allies. If Tymora was unaffected by a magical spell, the spell was turned back on the caster with full effect. Any form of spells or powers that were used to control her will or dominate her mind were instantly nullified.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Tyr
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


Tyr was portrayed as blind or with a bloody bandage over his eyes and missing his right hand, and he did not try to hide or bandage his stump. He usually was shown as a burly, noble warrior with a powerful build and a bearded face.
Tyr was strong-spirited and noble.He was considered the bravest and the most honorable of all the Aesir of the Norse pantheon.He was primarily concerned with the punishment of wrong-doers and the general furthering of law and good in the world. Tyr hated duplicity, trickery, rule-breaking, and wanton destruction. He likewise hated lies and the breaking of oaths and was disgusted by persons who earned from such things. For his own part, he never would break a promise.
Tyr urged the establishment of moral and ethical codes for sentient beings in all lands.
Tyr was a fair judge, but he was hard to understand to those outside his faith, as they more readily perceived him as a stern and rigid punisher. On the other hand, he was seen as a brave father-figure to his followers. In truth, he was well aware that a lawful utopia would never be possible in the imperfect Material Plane, yet this did not stop him from trying to make the world a better place for his mortal followers. He wanted his followers to see themselves as a "perfect family", not made of perfect individuals but rather of members who tried and wanted to be perfect, who acted out of trust, courage, and love toward each other. His knowledge that such a dream would never be achieved among the mortal realm filled him with genuine sadness.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Umberlee
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "-"


The Queen of the Depths was known as a particularly malicious, petty, greedy, and vain deity who controlled the harshness of the sea while revelling in her own power and was not hesitant to drown people if she so pleased. She did not feel a moral obligation to honour any of her agreements or promises if the end result was not beneficial to her. That, and her desire for the valuables and excessive tribute, demonstrated her insatiable greed and cruelty. She was power-hungry and loved exercising it, toying with her worshipers. She fed her sadistic nature by destroying naval vessels and feeding shipwreck victims to her sharks while watching others drown.
It was a typical tribute among sailors and ship crews to toss gems, gold, and valuables overboard to appease Umberlee and calm the storming waters. On cargo ships, the sailors often tossed the transported valuable trade goods overboard to gain favorable winds, while the sounds of mouthpipes played tunes dedicated to the goddess. When the danger was especially severe, the sailors made sure the goods tossed overboard contained living creatures. Before a voyage, sailors often left small tokens on Umberlee's shrine altars in hopes of calm waters. The most common tributes were flowers, candles, coins, and candy. Such tributes were also often paid by merchants who transported their trade cargo by sea, the townsfolk of coastal cities and islands who did not have a powerful patron deity and were in danger of storms and hurricanes.
Druids who worshiped the First Circle also venerated Umberlee, as she was a representation of nature in its cruel form.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Valkur
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Vahl-kurh"


Valkur's avatar appeared as a 10‑foot-tall (3‑meter) man of broad girth with a full black beard and brown eyes that sparkled with derring-do. He had a great belly laugh, but when driven to anger his voice would crack like rolling thunder. He was often depicted wading through the ocean, the water only coming up to his knees, and was known to actually make such appearances.
As buffeted by uncountable storms as he seemed, Valkur always looked dapper. His fantastic captain's outfit consisted of a blue frock coat with gold braid trim and brass buttons over a colorful brocade vest and white shirt with a ruffled collar and cuffs, along with knee-length trousers, hose, and shoes, with silver buckles. His tricorn hat shared the same color scheme, blue but trimmed in gold braid, and featured a large, white plume.
Valkur often manifested as an aurora borealis or aurora australis and sailors swore he appeared to becalmed ships at sea as a ghostly wind in which his image could be faintly glimpsed. Sometimes he manifested as a ghostly ship on the horizon, which always sailed to the nearest port but never seemed to get closer or farther away.
Valkur was served by many intelligent and benevolent animals, including dolphins, whales (especially narwhals), and sea birds. He used the latter to indicate his mood, manifesting as a silver albatross or gull drifting on the wind currents to indicate his favor and as a night black raven to convey his displeasure.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Waukeen
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Wah-Keh-een"


Waukeen was portrayed as a slender, young woman with long, lustrous golden hair; always splendidly dressed. Some depictions included a pair of golden lions resting at her feet. Her avatar was 10 ft (3 m) tall and typically had eyes that appeared as solid gold. She wore a gown woven from strips of precious metals polished to a gleaming finish and sprinkled with all manner of gemstones. Her sash was of spun gold and her cloak was a lattice of gold coins. On her feet were boots of laced pearls with gold soles.
On occasions where subtlety was more appropriate, the Golden Lady sometimes manifested as a sprouting of daffodils to give a sign of favor, hope, or inspiration. Often she would provide money in unexpected places, like a coin, face-up, to indicate the correct path at an intersection, or nuggets of gold, citrines, pyrite (also known as fool's gold—perhaps as a sign of disfavor). Slightly less subtle was a pair of golden eyes observing from a curtain of impenetrable darkness; or a large stack of gold coins that writhed like a snake, flying or wrapping itself around something or someone to which she wanted to draw attention before it shattered and scattered, often causing a scramble to collect them. All such tokens from the goddess were highly valued by Waukeenar as "divine essence of the goddess". When more interaction or aid was needed she could send creatures such as golden-colored cats, lock lurkers, golden lions, palomino horses, eagles (preferably golden ones), or extraplanar creatures such as ferrumachs and plumachs.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Material Plane
item.description:
#Caladonia

A place of balance between the elements and spirits, the Material Plane is the most stable form of conglomerated existence in accordance to beings of primal energies. Zerromonia is only one such place among a near infinite multitude hidden from each other, separated by an Astral Ocean of void and stars.
Another such Plane has crossed over a few times, a place called #Caladonia

item.title: Shadowfell
item.description:
A dimension of barren stretches of dark, overcast wasteland. A land where fears grow, sadness grow, and the lost wander endlessly without hope of relief or escape. A reflection of the material plane, though a reflection in a stained and dark mirror, the realm is akin to the most empty outcome of the material plane. Residents, if there are any that do live in this endless expanse devoid of most life, have gone insane with the shadows chasing them from any shelter, felt the deep stabbing loss of everything taken away from them, and forever wander without landmarks or settlement to lead them in any direction. Slowly, the prey of the deprived become another addition to the forgotten.

item.title: The Feywild
item.description:
A place of hopes and dreams, the realm sits just on the edge between Material Plane and the Elemental Planes of Existence. It is a realm which manifests beings, creatures, and places based on living entities on Material Plane, specifically what they literally hope and dream for or about. Workers that long to return to their favorite tavern to drink and sing merry songs begin to have those wishes manifest in The Feywild. Children who see the trees and shrubs of the forest as animals allow them to manifest in The Feywild as living moving beings. Parties, songs, dances, ceremonies, endless whismy and fun can all find themselves at the heart of the culture of The Feywild.
But beware, for the same can be said if a person hopes or dreams of violence, downfall, or death. The realm is dream made reality; and should those dreams become nightmares, then the realm will become one as a result.
