item.title: Amun-Ra
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Ah-moon-Rah" 🔰 Group Database Dataview: No results to show for table query.

Introduction The Amun people are expressive and emotionally driven, and tend to be very specialized in what they know and do. This has been their way for ages, as they are unchallenged masters sailors of sea and sand. The Amun people are avid magical relic hunters, seeking the greatest payout they can no matter the cost to the recipient. They are hard working people who never question the difficulty of a task so long as the reward is generous, and are willing to take immense risk if it doubles their gains.
Settlements 📝 Add New Settlement Dataview: No results to show for table query.

The established history of pre-Amun founding is all but lost to the sandsea and time. Records from unreliably chaotic archeological discoveries and exceedingly scarce written materials, pre-Amun depictions regarded the entire continent a magical and technical paradise; something greater than the paramount of a golden age. Vague descriptions include pictures of cities of mirrors and glass the size and height of ancient forests; technology able to combat any curse, disease, and even aging; control over beasts from other realms and dimensions. But what had caused its disappearance remains a dauntlessly endless mystery...

The Amun people are ruled over by an Absolute Theocracy. Their Godking, Atam’hekten, has defined the laws of the land before which even Arcædian historians started recording. The Amun people do not know how long their ruler has sat within his palace and no one has seen this ruler in person and came back the same as they were, but his presence is felt throughout the nation. Otherwise, often the person who has obtained the most relics is often in charge of smaller, indiscernible districts of towns or caravans. While some are artisanal leaders, others are part of organized crime. And the only ones above them are their Godking.

The Amun have a monopoly on glassmaking, spices, "Dune Spice", special woven fabrics found only in their particular region, and rare minerals that only come from the wastes and sandsea. They also export and import exotic animals of which they catch from various places. As a food source, they rely on the fruits and fish that they gather from the seaside or along the few oases, if not also sparse animal herding. The Amun people prefer to haggle, finding a middle ground over time through pressure and tactical charisma. Prices start high, bids rebuttal low, and through perfect negotiation, both come out on top.
Most Amun are artisans and traders, attempting to accumulate enough wealth to lift up their social status. If an Amun is not up for trade work, relic hunting through the seas and/or dunes can bring about a large sum of money and reputation. Some might even say the country subsides on piracy and graverobbery.

Amun-Ra has thin diplomatic relations with other territories, at best. The scarlet corsair pirates that arise from the kingdom are always a note of concern, though the Amun Theocracy will always declare no relation to the pirates, nor any real intention to stop them. Trade relationships are often the best between Amun-Ra and other countries. Their ships are often the fastest to sail, the merchants have fear of nothing at sea, and they will trade nearly anything, for the right price.
The Amun also have relations with the nomadic tribes of the sandsea, often hiring them as guides, messengers, or mercenaries.

The Amun are masters at marine warfare, and unconventional land warfare. 
The Weave Wind Ships of the Amun are fast, and extremely maneuverable, utilizing the winds with the highest proficiency with a mixture of careful, culturally shared engineering and very specialized training, with a hint of Arcane Weave mixed into the clothe of the sails. Weave Wind Warships seen on the horizon are a fight not worth fighting, as they will circle your ship far sooner than you could get a broadside off. Scarlet Sails seen on the horizon are a death sentence.
On Land, the Amun utilize animals to their advantage. Swarms of war carrions, legions of mounted elephants, Camel Caravans, armored hyenas, and furthermore to the imagination. It is not uncommon for many to summon creatures from other realms to fight for them, or to raise the dead.

The Amun-Rae are not known to have Arcane power, and it is very rare to see any who present a talent for it. Those that are born with such powers are more than often forced into servitude, never learning more than what they naturally discover. It is not unheard of for high noble citizens to flaunt their "indentured" magic users by making them cast their magic on mundane tasks. Even if Amun Magic Users did develop their magic skills, their powers would be severally diminished due to the volatile weave in Amun-Ra. Wizards and Sorcerers from other nations scarcely visit Amun-Ra, more apt to send others to find the relics of ancient times for them.
At present, magic items are their only stable source of what they can call their own “magic”. Since long before written history, something happened in Amun-Ra's past that has caused the area to be incapable of developing magic on its own. Prolonged magic dies out sooner than it should be intended, rituals fail often unless sources are kept close and constant, and in some areas of the sandsea may cause chaotic eruptions of magic from the spellcaster.

The Amun-Rae generally worship their Godking who has been upon the throne for longer than the histories of Arcædia can record.
Some residents will worship ancient gods in secret, though it is unknown if they return their call. Anyone caught is declared a heretic, and publicly executed by the local guard who are also under the control and rule of the Godking and his demands.

item.title: Arcaedia
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Arh-kay-dee-ya" 🔰 Group Database

Introduction After centuries of war for control over the auspicious western continent, the Arcædian Dominion establishes that it was one of the oldest human territories to have settled themselves and built lasting cities in the Western lands. The Dominion covers almost the entire Western Continent and has enveloped many of the humanoid races together under one banner. The flags of Arcædia are variations of a White Lion roaring, and are colored to each regional major city.
Settlements 📝 Add New Settlement Dataview: No results to show for table query.

Before it was a nation united under one banner, the continent was riddled with war from all directions. Savage Orc Tribes, Power Hungry Lords, Civil Wars, Power Struggles between Nations hardly known, Secret Wars fought hidden along mountains and in deep ravines; there was scarcely a time when battle and bloodshed did not saturate the earth. Over the course of centuries, eight mighty heroes bound the nation together with diplomacy, triumph, and infamous glory. They are remembered and immortalized through the Pillars of Archons, housed at the central hill within the deemed capital city of Arcædia so that their efforts would not be forgotten in forming the now mostly peaceful kingdom.

Arcædia is a mixed form of Independent City-States, Aristocracy, and Elective Monarchy. Each metropolis city is technically its own capital in its region, with its own noble houses, and government and laws. However, there is a massive set of legal agreements set down long ago that dictate that the laws of the first founded city, Vasaros, would be treated as law above all others. The City-States follow in the establishment of Vasaros, while setting its own laws for the region of which it rules over. In Vasaros, the Nobles have the highest level of control in the government, under only the elected Emperor. The Emperor, however, does not rule with absolute power, and can be overthrown by the Aristocracy, within reason. The Emperor acts as the greater representative of Arcædia to foreign powers, and establishes any final say in arguments for what he/she believes will help the empire as a whole, ideally.

Arcædia’s influence spreads fairly large but does not go beyond the Fe’wylds, which is in complete control of the Wood Elves. Thus, diplomatic relations are generally well established. The Arcædian Empire has soured relations with the Hvelgamir nation in the North but does not often deal with Raids by rogue groups in relation to the area. Arcædia knows about but does its best not to openly acknowledge the information it has on the other empires, and their massive cultural and governmental differences in order to maintain the long established global trading economy with Wuzhia and Amun-Ra. 

Arcædia’s economy is vastly varied per regional city: Fishing(both freshwater and coastal), mining and masonry, farming and distilleries, lumber and carpentry, etc. But all are protected by the Arcædian Coalition for Mercantile Economics, which oversees import and export between cities and territories. Highways between major cities are built and maintained by The Capital City of Vassaros, which allows for the fastest route of materials and processed goods to reach across the Dominion.

Arcædia’s military is varied but strong in large numbers. The military had agreed to maintain highways between the major cities in order to send troops between cities with expediency. It is not uncommon to pass through multiple checkpoints along the highways, as merchants will also use these roads since they are the fastest ways between markets.
Southern Arcædian military specialize in Cavalry, since horses are fairly abundant on the plains and grassy hillands. Foot soldiers are well trained for open area combat, taking advantage of crossbows and shields. Northern Arcædia specializes in Rangers, preferring to take advantage of the rough and dense terrains of the forest and mountainous areas. The large swathes of trees make (anti-)siege weaponry manufacturing very accessible.

Arcædians are fairly well rounded, though Magic is not as common as one would hope. What is common is seeing shops hire sparse wizards to cast enchantment on their shops to help advertise for higher prices. Shops that sell magical wears are expensive, and really only affordable by those with deep coin purses and the knowledge of what they are looking to acquire. However, it is not uncommon to see veterans of wars or explorers hold on to or display magical relics of their previous adventures.
There are dedicated colleges to the Arcane Arts, however deserted they may often be seen as, and each college does its research into the manipulation and behaviors of the arcane weave and power. Sometimes old discoveries are reconfirmed over and over, sometimes a forbidden stumble upon takes place. Each college has a rule set to the research, and forbidden knowledge and practices that none dare to perform, unless a critical circumstance calls for it.
Most Arcædian Magic comes from the long history of research from predecessor ruins. Thus, most of their magic is influenced by Elven/Fey presence and rituals.

True Arcædians don’t have a single religion that they commune to. Most often, they regard all religious deities as part of the same being or beings, just in different forms. The old word for these beings was Numen, but the recent decades of multicultural and multiracial integrations has led them to call them the commonword Aspects. The temples in any divine districts are considered homes to the deities, where often ancient forms or newly made sculptural figures, where offerings are sometimes given, or inspiration can be drawn from by being in the figure's presence. Worship is generally done within the temples led by priests, to interpret the doctrine of these Aspects.

item.title: Hvelgemir
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Hv-el-ghem-eer" 🔰 Group Database Dataview: No results to show for table query.

Introduction The Hvergelmir are a hardy and large people, often mistaken for those with giant’s blood. They pride themselves on their size, their constitution, and their relentlessness in a fight. Their homelands are from the north, where the cold is as much a monster as a dragon would be, and the monsters are as dragon-like as the Winters. They do not like the help from others, even of their own kind and pride themselves in their strength in themselves. They have a history of raiding various territories since they can often go unchallenged.
Settlements 📝 Add New Settlement Dataview: No results to show for table query.

No one knows how or why the northern lands were settled. All anyone knows is that they survived, and are continuing to survive. Perhaps they were warriors who wanted wanted freedom to fight as they wish. Perhaps they were monster hunters who wanted the greater challenge. Perhaps they were refugees who sought the only place of peace they could. Not even the oral tales of the shamans provide the true history. Stories of only Now, and how to keep surviving.

Hvergelmir rule themselves as individuals, but are completely community based which are also often led by whomever is the strongest warrior. The leader can be usurped if they are beaten in one on one combat, or if they fall ill or grow old. Thus, the elderly do not rule, unless somehow that elder is the strongest Hvergelmir in the community. Someone who kills the leader outside of honorable combat does not become the leader, and is not only not recognized as strong but also hunted down for their dishonor; as such, unless the traitor amasses enough behind them to claim their leadership and deny wrong doing, coup d'etat
Additionally, they are governed by the tradition of Nature. The natural order is everything to them. The frost gives and the frost takes. They may hunt for sport, but nothing is to go to waste. If a comrade dies in a hunt, it is not because they are weak, nature was simply stronger.

Though raiding parties occasionally are made through dishonest and dishonorable Hvergelmir warriors, they remain neutral to the world. Most do not wish to be bothered or bother, as there are far more direct problems that plague them in their lands than inviting more.

Most of Hvergelmir’s economy mostly is based on hunting and mercenary work. Beasts with thick pelts and leathers and chitinous shells are prized after by the other territories, among other parts from the monsters that terrorize the northern lands, as everything can be used as a resource in the hands of a Hvelgemir. Sellswords are also not uncommon; Hvelgemir guards for vaults or security teams are highly prized after, as with the right amount of pay hold to their loyalties of their buyer. Its also not unheard of to send kill squads to deal severe casualties to organizations. The boats of the Hvergelmir, although not as fast as the corsair of Amun-ra, are strong and are the only boats to be able to break through shallow waters and ice without falling apart.

Hvergelmir never needed an organized military force. Each person is their own army, and are trained so from birth to adulthood. They are known for their relentlessness in combat, are quick to rush a vanguard, and do not retreat. They do not believe in prisoners of war and will fight to the death to avoid capture. If they are captured, they will simply become raging monsters, and become a constantly hostile beast that causes more problems than simply killing them.

Most Hvergelmir do not hone arcane powers. Those that do are considered beings of gifted power by ancient beings, and are treated as separate entities in society, often religious in nature without actual worship. They are not regarded as strong individuals to Hvergelmir culture, and do not take full leadership roles in a community, but that does not mean they should be trifled with. Often, their advice is readily headed in understanding the nature of the frost.

The Hvergelmir do not typically worship deities or beings of power. They worship the art of combat, and revere the power of nature and beasts. Death by combat is the ultimate ascension. If a Hvergelmir takes actions that are considered dishonorable, they are freely hunted down by other Hvergelmir, and it is considered just for both the community and the wrongful Hvergelmir warrior, allowing him or her to fight to the very end.

item.title: Wuzhia
item.description:
Infobox Pronounced: "Woo-ji-ah" 🔰 Group Database Dataview: No results to show for table query.

Introduction The Wuzhia are a strange people; without grey in their philosophies or personalities. Some are expressive, happy, socially active. Others are simply passive and unspeaking. All Wuzhia people prefer peaceful lives, and many seek to enlighten themselves. They often make great advisors and generals for their loyalty, bluntness, and ability to keep things on point. Others are hired on as skilled, niche artisans or Arcane Masters to further arcane discoveries. They are highly disciplined people that live strict lifestyles, for better or for worse.



Wuzhia is governed by a complex series of lawmakers, enforcers, and religious control through a Dynastic Ruler. The Jade Empress currently presides over the entirety of the country, though what her actual role in the government is and how much power she has in it is not well understood. Highly prestigious organizations run by highly acclaimed “families” are more often the leaders of towns or districts of larger cities. The rules set by lawmakers are very strict and infallible in their direction, such that it is very easy to follow and break a law.

Wuzhia is on good terms with all nations on an overall military and economic relationship. Trade of resources and information are readily exchanged. Wuzhia is swift to take down pirates upon their waters, and assist other nations in their plights. They are quick to provide aid, and ready to send workers and supplies wherever they are requested. This quick response to help has garnered both a happy intake of support, but also a mild suspicion of their motives.

Wuzhia’s economy is vast and varying. They are known for their rices, fruits, vegetables, exotic plants and insects, and meats; their culinary arts could even be considered a resource that is traded. Minerals and gemstones vary greatly and are highly sought after for enhancing magical properties. Wuzhia is also known for magic to be far more common among its territories than the others, and higher quality magical equipment, scrolls, and sources often come from Wuzhia.

The military potential of Wuzhia is unknown, not because it is hidden, but because they are overtly open about their ability to martial themselves. They have an open military presence among their citizens, and with magic being heavily prominent among nearly all residents, nearly everyone can defend themselves both by martial combat and arcane spells. Military Strategy and Philosophy is a basic subject to Wuzhia students, even if many do not fall into the practice as a career.

Nearly all Wuzhia have natural arcane talents. Those that don’t will often be taught supplemental material in order to learn arcane power. Even martial warriors within Wuzhia ranks will utilize their arcane abilities in combat, allowing them to overwhelm anyone with blade and spell. Magical items or enchantments are extremely common in Wuzhia communities, and are often traded between individuals who can make or have access to these items.

Wuzhia worships dragons as the highest form. They believe that if one can ascend into a dragon, they become all powerful in this material plane. And if they can ascend as a dragon, they can achieve spiritual perfection into apotheosis. Good and Evil are fallacies, flaws developed by flawed beings, and instead each dragon is associated with a type of personality to be empowered. Many citizens will don a specific color or accessory in order to empower them in the sense of what the dragon represents. Ironically, Dragonborn are not regarded the same as their ancestors, and rank like any other citizen among the people. You would likely see a Gold Dragonborn servant as much as you would see a White Dragonborn noble.

item.title: Absorb Elements
item.description:
Infobox




The spell captures some of the incoming energy, lessening its effect on you and storing it for your next melee attack. You have resistance to the triggering damage type until the start of your next turn. Also, the first time you hit with a melee attack on your next turn, the target takes an extra 1d6 damage of the triggering type, and the spell ends.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the extra damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.
*material components - which you take when you take acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage

item.title: Counterspell
item.description:
Infobox




You attempt to interrupt a creature in the process of casting a spell. If the creature is casting a spell of 3rd level or lower, its spell fails and has no effect. If it is casting a spell of 4th level or higher, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a success, the creature's spell fails and has no effect.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the interrupted spell has no effect if its level is less than or equal to the level of the spell slot you used.


which you take when you see a creature within 60 feet of you casting a spell

item.title: Dispel Magic
item.description:
Infobox





Choose one creature, object, or magical effect within range. Any spell of 3rd level or lower on the target ends. For each spell of 4th level or higher on the target, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell’s level. On a successful check, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you automatically end the effects of a spell on the target if the spell's level is equal to or less than the level of the spell slot you used.

item.title: Greater Restoration
item.description:
Infobox




You imbue a creature you touch with positive energy to undo a debilitating effect. You can reduce the target's exhaustion level by one, or end one of the following effects on the target:

One effect that charmed the target
One curse, including the target's attunement to a cursed magic item
Any reduction to one of the target's ability scores
One effect reducing the target's hit point maximum


(diamond dust worth at least 100 gp, which the spell consumes)

Infobox




You create a bonfire on ground that you can see within range. Until the spell ends, the bonfire fills a 5-foot cube. Any creature in the bonfire’s space when you cast the spell must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 1d8 fire damage. A creature must also make the saving throw when it enters the bonfire’s space for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there.
At Higher Levels. The spell’s damage increases by 1d8 when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

item.title: Planar Ally
item.description:
Infobox





You beseech an otherworldly entity for aid. The being must be known to you: a god, a primordial, a demon prince, or some other being of cosmic power. That entity sends a celestial, an elemental, or a fiend loyal to it to aid you, making the creature appear in an unoccupied space within range. If you know a specific creature's name, you can speak that name when you cast this spell to request that creature, though you might get a different creature anyway (GM's choice).
When the creature appears, it is under no compulsion to behave in any particular way. You can ask the creature to perform a service in exchange for payment, but it isn't obliged to do so. The requested task could range from simple (fly us across the chasm, or help us fight a battle) to complex (spy on our enemies, or protect us during our foray into the dungeon). You must be able to communicate with the creature to bargain for its services.
Payment can take a variety of forms. A celestial might require a sizable donation of gold or magic items to an allied temple, while a fiend might demand a living sacrifice or a gift of treasure. Some creatures might exchange their service for a quest undertaken by you.
As a rule of thumb, a task that can be measured in minutes requires a payment worth 100 gp per minute. A task measured in hours requires 1,000 gp per hour. And a task measured in days (up to 10 days) requires 10,000 gp per day. The GM can adjust these payments based on the circumstances under which you cast the spell. If the task is aligned with the creature's ethos, the payment might be halved or even waived. Nonhazardous tasks typically require only half the suggested payment, while especially dangerous tasks might require a greater gift. Creatures rarely accept tasks that seem suicidal.
After the creature completes the task, or when the agreed-upon duration of service expires, the creature returns to its home plane after reporting back to you, if appropriate to the task and if possible. If you are unable to agree on a price for the creature's service, the creature immediately returns to its home plane.
A creature enlisted to join your group counts as a member of it, receiving a full share of experience points awarded.

item.title: Detect Magic
item.description:
Infobox




For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any. The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Hunter's Mark
item.description:
Infobox






You choose a creature you can see within range and mystically mark it as your quarry. Until the spell ends, you deal an extra 1d6 damage to the target whenever you hit it with a weapon attack, and you have advantage on any Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Survival) check you make to find it. If the target drops to 0 hit points before this spell ends, you can use a bonus action on a subsequent turn of yours to mark a new creature.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd or 4th level, you can maintain your Concentration on the spell for up to 8 hours. When you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you can maintain your concentr⁠ation on the spell for up to 24 hours.

item.title: Identify
item.description:
Infobox





You choose one object that you must touch throughout the casting of the spell. If it is a magic item or some other magic-imbued object, you learn its properties and how to use them, whether it requires attunement to use, and how many charges it has, if any. You learn whether any spells are affecting the item and what they are. If the item was created by a spell, you learn which spell created it.
If you instead touch a creature throughout the casting, you learn what spells, if any, are currently affecting it.
*material components - (a pearl worth at least 100 gp and an owl feather)

item.description:
Infobox




You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.


(a sprinkling of holy water)

item.title: Zone of Truth
item.description:
Infobox




You create a magical zone that guards against deception in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on a point of your choice within range. Until the spell ends, a creature that enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, a creature can't speak a deliberate lie while in the radius. You know whether each creature succeeds or fails on its saving throw.
An affected creature is aware of the spell and can thus avoid answering questions to which it would normally respond with a lie. Such a creature can be evasive in its answers as long as it remains within the boundaries of the truth.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Booming Blade
item.description:
Infobox




You brandish the weapon used in the spell’s casting and make a melee attack with it against one creature within 5 feet of you. On a hit, the target suffers the weapon attack’s normal effects and then becomes sheathed in booming energy until the start of your next turn. If the target willingly moves 5 feet or more before then, the target takes 1d8 thunder damage, and the spell ends.
At Higher Levels. At 5th level, the melee attack deals an extra 1d8 thunder damage to the target on a hit, and the damage the target takes for moving increases to 2d8. Both damage rolls increase by 1d8 at 11th level (2d8 and 3d8) and again at 17th level (3d8 and 4d8).
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Branding Smite
item.description:
Infobox





The next time you hit a creature with a weapon attack before this spell ends, the weapon gleams with astral radiance as you strike. The attack deals an extra 2d6 radiant damage to the target, which becomes visible if it is invisible, and the target sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius and can’t become invisible until the spell ends. 
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the extra damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

item.description:
Infobox





A creature you touch regains a number of hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

item.title: Faerie Fire
item.description:
Infobox





Each object in a 20-foot cube within range is outlined in blue, green, or violet light (your choice). Any creature in the area when the spell is cast is also outlined in light if it fails a Dexterity saving throw. For the duration, objects and affected creatures shed dim light in a 10-foot radius. Any attack roll against an affected creature or object has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature or object can’t benefit from being invisible.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Fireball
item.description:
Infobox





A bright streak flashes from your pointing finger to a point you choose within range and then blossoms with a low roar into an explosion of flame. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 8d6 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The fire spreads around corners. It ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.


(a tiny ball of bat guano and sulfur)

Infobox




A flash of light streaks toward a creature of your choice within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 4d6 radiant damage, and the next attack roll made against this target before the end of your next turn has advantage, thanks to the mystical dim light glittering on the target until then. At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.

item.title: Lay on Hands
item.description:
Infobox





Your blessed touch can heal wounds. You have a pool of healing power that replenishes when you take a long rest. With that pool, you can restore a total number of hit points equal to your paladin level x 5.
As an action, you can touch a creature and draw power from the pool to restore a number of hit points to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in your pool.
Alternatively, you can expend 5 hit points from your pool of healing to cure the target of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting it. You can cure multiple diseases and neutralize multiple poisons with a single use of Lay on Hands, expending hit points separately for each one.
This feature has no effect on undead and constructs.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Mass Healing Word
item.description:
Infobox






As you call out words of restoration, up to six creatures of your choice that you can see within range regain hit points equal to 1d4 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the Healing increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 3rd.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Mystic Missile
item.description:
Infobox




Arcane energy is crystallized in psionic shards and propelled at a target within range, finding purchase by the same means as the infamous Magic Missile, but with some astounding effects!
You fire three crystalline shards that automatically hit and burst, dealing 1d4+1 force damage each. The shards all strike simultaneously, and you can direct them to hit one creature or several. A residual cloud of unstable Arcane Energy lingers from the impact. The target or targets must then roll an Intelligence Saving Throw. On a failed save, you must
roll a 1d6 to determine the effect of the residual cloud for all creatures struck

Charmed - the creature(s) calms and seems enamored by the caster. 
A charmed creature can’t Attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful Abilities or magical Effects.
The charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature.
Despair - the creature(s) seem to have some sort of realization, and break down
A restrained creature’s speed becomes 0, and it can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed.
Attack rolls against the creature have advantage, and the creature’s Attack rolls have disadvantage.
The creature has disadvantage on Dexterity Saving Throws.
Frightened - the creature(s) look at the caster, and fear reels in their eyes!
A frightened creature has disadvantage on Ability Checks and Attack rolls while the source of its fear is within line of sight.
The creature can’t willingly move closer to the source of its fear.
Enraged - the creature(s) is seems to go berserk in a fit of sudden rage
The creature uses its immediate reaction to make a single melee attack against the closest creature.
The creature then uses its turn to attack the closest creature.
Dazed - the creature(s) grab at their head, seeming to be unable to stand straight or pay attention
The creature is unable to act normally. A dazed creature can take no actions, but has no penalty to AC.
Only lasts for the round.
Exhaustion - the creature(s) seem suddenly, heavily fatigued, sweating and at a loss of breath

On a successful save, no magical effect affects the creature.
At the beginning of an affected creatures turn, it must make an intelligence saving throw to dispel the effect lingering effects, except Exhaustion.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the spell creates one more dart for each slot level above 1st.

A sudden loud ringing noise, painfully intense, erupts from a point of your choice within range. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 3d8 thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A nonmagical object that isn’t being worn or carried also takes the damage if it’s in the spell’s area.

item.title: Knock
item.description:
Infobox





Choose an object that you can see within range. The object can be a door, a box, a chest, a set of manacles, a padlock, or another object that contains a mundane or magical means that prevents access.
A target that is held shut by a mundane lock or that is stuck or barred becomes unlocked, unstuck, or unbarred. If the object has multiple locks, only one of them is unlocked.
If you choose a target that is held shut with arcane lock, that spell is suppressed for 10 minutes, during which time the target can be opened and shut normally.
When you cast the spell, a loud knock, audible from as far away as 300 feet, emanates from the target object.

item.title: Wind Walk
item.description:
Infobox





You and up to ten willing creatures you can see within range assume a gaseous form for the duration, appearing as wisps of cloud. While in this cloud form, a creature has a flying speed of 300 feet and has resistance to damage from nonmagical weapons. The only actions a creature can take in this form are the Dash action or to revert to its normal form. Reverting takes 1 minute, during which time a creature is incapacitated and can’t move. Until the spell ends, a creature can revert to cloud form, which also requires the 1-minute transformation. If a creature is in cloud form and flying when the effect ends, the creature descends 60 feet per round for 1 minute until it lands, which it does safely. If it can’t land after 1 minute, the creature falls the remaining distance.

item.title: Necklace of Prayer Beads
item.description:
Infobox


The Necklace of Prayer Beads has 1d4 + 2 magic beads made from aquamarine, black pearl, or topaz. It also has many nonmagical beads made from stones such as amber, bloodstone, citrine, coral, jade, pearl, or quartz. If a magic bead is removed from the necklace, that bead loses its magic.
Six types of magic beads exist. The GM decides the type of each bead on the necklace or determines it randomly. A necklace can have more than one bead of the same type. To use one, you must be wearing the necklace. Each bead contains a spell that you can cast from it as a bonus action (using your spell save DC if a save is necessary). Once a magic bead's spell is cast, that bead can't be used again until the next dawn.


Currently held by Evan.

item.title: Black Seal
item.description:
Infobox


The Black Seal is a black ring with a black gem that seems to swirl like a dark mist.
Souldrinker: The ring cna hold 6 charges. You gain 1 charge whenever you kill(or actively assist in the killing of) a creature. As a Bonus Action, you can activate one of the effects by spending charges.

Dark Presence (1 Charge): Surround yourself with an ominous aura that grants you an advantage on Intimidation Checks for 1 hour.
Black Cloak (2 Charges): Cloaks your body in darkness, granting +1 to your AC and you gain an Advantage on all Stealth Checks for the next 10 Minutes.
Soulstrike (6 Charges): Your next 3 weapon attacks (within 10 minutes) deal an additional 3d6 Necrotic damage.
CURSED: If there is at least one chage in the ring and you take a Long Rest, make a Wisdom Saving Throw (DC 14). On a failure, you do not gain the benefits of the rest as your dreams are filled with visions of the souls trapped in the ring.

Currently being held by Ronpip. It is not currently in use.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Cursed Ring of Seething
item.description:
Infobox


The Cursed Ring of Seething is cool to the touch and has several cracks throughout its otherwise smooth body. When you attune to the ring, choose a creature type: aberration, celestial, dragon, elemental, fey, fiend, or undead. While wearing the ring, its normally cool band begins to grow hot when a creature of the selected type is within 60 feet of you. In addition, you have advantage on any saving throws you make to resist being charmed or frightened by a creature of that selected type. While seemingly radiating heat, it feels only warm against your skin. Small flecks of the metal hover just above the surface of the ring when glowing in this way.
Curse. Once you attune to the ring and place it on your finger, you can’t remove it unless targeted by a remove curse spell. While cursed, you have disadvantage on any Charisma or Wisdom (Insight) checks you make that involve a creature of the selected type. In addition, while within 60 feet of one or more creatures of that type, you have disadvantage on any attack roll you make that targets a creature of a different type.

When Evan put on this Ring in Session 07 and chose Fey.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Ring/Cursed Ring of Seething.md

item.description:
Infobox


The Ring of Protection provides a +1 bonus to AC and saving throws while wearing this ring.

Currently worn by Ronpip.

item.title: Ring of Shooting Stars
item.description:
Infobox


The Ring of Shooting Stars appears a brass and silver ring with a glinting amethyst, like a purple star suspended in space within the gemstone.
While wearing this ring in dim light or darkness, you can cast dancing lights and light from the ring at will. Casting either spell from the ring requires an action.
The ring has 6 charges for the following other properties. The ring regains 1d6 expended charges daily at dawn.
Faerie Fire: You can expend 1 charge as an action to cast faerie fire from the ring.
Ball Lightning: You can expend 2 charges as an action to create one to four 3-foot-diameter spheres of lightning. The more spheres you create, the less powerful each sphere is individually.
Each sphere appears in an unoccupied space you can see within 120 feet of you. The spheres last as long as you concentrate (as if concentrating on a spell), up to 1 minute. Each sphere sheds dim light in a 30-foot radius.
As a bonus action, you can move each sphere up to 30 feet, but no farther than 120 feet away from you. When a creature other than you comes within 5 feet of a sphere, the sphere discharges lightning at that creature and disappears. That creature must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes lightning damage based on the number of spheres you created. (4 spheres = 2d4, 3 spheres = 2d6, 2 spheres = 5d4, 1 sphere = 4d12)
Shooting Stars: You can expend 1 to 3 charges as an action. For every charge you expend, you launch a glowing mote of light from the ring at a point you can see within 60 feet of you. Each creature within a 15-foot cube originating from that point is showered in sparks and must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 5d4 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Currently being worn by Evan.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Ring/Ring of Shooting Stars.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Rod of Elements
item.description:
Infobox


The Rod of Elements is a multifaceted rod of multiple colored jewels. The rod is capable of casting certain elemental spells, up to a point. While holding the rod, the wielder is resistant to elemental damage passively.

Hysseld gave the party the item temporarily, and the item was returned in Session 03.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Scroll of Chill Touch
item.description:
Infobox


The Scroll of Chill Touch is a magic scroll inscribed with the spell Chill Touch.





You create a ghostly, skeletal hand in the space of a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the creature to assail it with the chill of the grave. On a hit, the target takes 1d8 necrotic damage, and it can't regain hit points until the start of your next turn. Until then, the hand clings to the target.
If you hit an undead target, it also has disadvantage on attack rolls against you until the end of your next turn.
This spell's damage increases by 2d8.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Scroll/Scroll of Chill Touch.md

item.title: Scroll of Identify
item.description:
Infobox


The Scroll of Identify is a scroll inscribed with the spell Identify


You choose one object that you must touch throughout the casting of the spell. If it is a magic item or some other magic-imbued object, you learn its properties and how to use them, whether it requires attunement to use, and how many charges it has, if any. You learn whether any spells are affecting the item and what they are. If the item was created by a spell, you learn which spell created it.
If you instead touch a creature throughout the casting, you learn what spells, if any, are currently affecting it.
*material components - (a pearl worth at least 100 gp and an owl feather)
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Scroll of Thorn Whip
item.description:
Infobox


The Scroll of Thorn Whip




You create a long, vine-like whip covered in thorns that lashes out at your command toward a creature in range. Make a melee spell attack against the target. If the attack hits, the creature takes 2d6 piercing damage, and if the creature is Large or smaller, you pull the creature up to 10 feet closer to you.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Scroll/Scroll of Thorn Whip.md

item.description:
Infobox


The Glass Bottle of the Acolyte is a small trinket that reminds a person that they are always watched by those of higher power, for better or for worse. Provides an Advantage on Religion Checks regarding Arcaedian accepted Religions.

Currently being held by Ronpip and Vimack.

item.title: Wand of Fireballs
item.description:
Infobox


The Wand of Fireballs has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the Fireball spell (save DC 15) from it. For 1 charge, you cast the 3rd-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.
The wand regains 1d6 + 1 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a d20. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed

Currently being held by Ronpip.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Dagger of Warning
item.description:
Infobox


The Dagger of Warning warns you of danger. While the weapon is on your person, you have advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, you and any of your companions within 30 feet of you can't be surprised, except when incapacitated by something other than nonmagical sleep.

Currently being held by Ronpip.

item.description:
Infobox


The Katzbalger of the Promising Hero a short sword crafted by ancient Arcaedian smiths for the empire, and blessed to help the next promising young hero.
+1 magical weapon that deals an additional 1d6 radiant damage on hit
Casts a dim light when unsheathe; can cast a 30ft bright light when a command word is spoken: Afret enmihen Lux

Currently being wielded by Vimack.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Weapon/Katzbalger of the Promising Hero.md

item.title: Moon Blessed Double Scimitar
item.description:
Infobox


The Moon Blessed Double Scimitar is a specially crafted ornate weapon wielded by Vadathaus Horreneth in Mira Esmirelda. In darkness, the unsheathed blade of this sword sheds moonlight, creating bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet.

Currently in Vimack's Bag of Holding.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Weapon/Moon Blessed Double Scimitar.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: The Sundering Blackiron
item.description:
Infobox


The Sundering Blackiron is sentient weapon. A perfectly smooth black metal finish offers only a faint, diffused reflection of iridescent light. The weapon almost hums and wavers slightly, but otherwise seems like an unassuming black metal weapon. None may hold the Blackiron and not feel the weight of its purpose, save for its chosen recipient. In the presence of another legendary weapon, it quivers in anticipation of battle against it. And to win so absolutely against the other weapon as unworthy.
-Weapon is treated as a +1 magical weapon

Battlehunger: it does an additional 1d6+1 of the weapon's damage to the first creature it successfully hits on your turn, or during an Attack of Opportunity, no matter its form.
Sunderer's Strike:
As part of an Attack Action using a melee weapon form, you may declare to Sunder the enemy's weapon, picking either an equipped weapon, shield, or attached natural weapon.
The enemy must make a Dexterity Saving Throw DC damage dealt to the target. On a successful save, the weapon is not Sundered. On a failed save, the weapon is utterly destroyed and cannot be used for the rest of the encounter, and the Sundering Blackiron counts as a +3 for the remainder of the encounter. On a Critical Strike, you automatically Sunder the target's weapon, even if you no longer have the ability to do so.
You may use this feature once per encounter unless it is a Critical Hit. You must declare that you are Sundering a weapon prior to rolling damage.
Breaker's Path:
As an action using a melee weapon form, you may momentarily slice through any physical, non-magical object magically, sundering itself from its own material. So long as the object being cut through is smaller than the length of the blade, you can fully separate the halves of the object with a perfect clean cut. You cannot cut flesh or living materials in this manner.
You may use this feature equal to your Charisma Modifier.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Bag of Bounty
item.description:
Infobox


The Bag of Bounty is a small leather bound pouch. When someone reaches into the Bag of Bounty, they pull out their preferred food or drink out of an interdimensional space. The food and drink that are pulled out are real, but not created by the bag...

Ronpip has pulled out Cherries and Thimbleville Mead Vimack has pulled out a warm glass of yak milk. Evan has pulled biscuits baked by his grandmother.
Currently held by Vimack
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Bag of Bounty.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Boots of Speed
item.description:
Infobox


The Boots of Speed are a set of unassuming leather boots. While you wear these boots, you can use a bonus action and click the boots' heels together. If you do, the boots double your walking speed, and any creature that makes an opportunity attack against you has disadvantage on the attack roll. If you click your heels together again, you end the effect.
When the boots' property has been used for a total of 10 minutes, the magic ceases to function until you finish a long rest.

Currently worn by Ronpip.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Boots of Speed.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Gauntlets of Flaming Fury
item.description:
Infobox


While you wear both of the Gauntlets of Flaming Fury, any non-magical weapon you grasp with either gauntlet is treated as a magic weapon. As a bonus action, you can use the gauntlets to cause magical flames to envelop one or two melee weapons in your grasp. Each flaming weapon deals an extra 1d6 fire damage on a hit. The flames last until you sheath or let go of either weapon. Once used, this property can’t be used again until the next dawn.

Currently being held by Lorellai.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Gauntlets of Flaming Fury.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Gauntlets of Heavenly Ascension
item.description:
Infobox


The Gauntlets of Heavenly Ascension are large golden rings are held together with seemingly unknown force are worn like gauntlets. To any common person, they are simply valuable for their material, despite being unable to break it down. But to those touched by the Astral Plane and gifted in psionics, these bracers let them store a prepared manifestation of their power within them in preparation for an attack. A telepathic voice speaks to the wielder of psionic power, reminding them what power is stored within the gauntlets, and reassuring them during moments of mental attacks.
As part of a short or long rest, or standard action while in battle, you can store up a power from a Psionic discipline that costs up to 5 psi points and manifests as a standard action. Any time a weapon from the wielder strikes a creature and the creature takes damage from it, the weapon can immediately manifest the power on that creature as a reaction if the wielder desires. Once the power is manifested, the power is used up, and the user can spend those points on another power to imbue into the gauntlets.
Psi Points spent in this way are not recovered until they are spent from the Gauntlet. They cannot be recovered during a short or long rest if they are spent within the gauntlet. You can withdraw the spent psi points from the gauntlet as part of a short or long rest.
Additionally, while wearing these, you have resistance to psychic damage, and an advantage against mental conditions(Frightened, Charmed, Stunned*).

Currently being worn by Evan.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Gauntlets of Heavenly Ascension.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Ion Stone of Intellect
item.description:
Infobox


The Ion Stone of Intellect is a marbled scarlet and blue sphere. You can use an action to toss this stone into the air, it orbits your head at a distance of 1d3 feet. While this stone orbits, your Intelligence score increases by 2, to a maximum of 20.

Currently being used by Evan
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Ion Stone of Intellect.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Lost & Found
item.description:
Infobox


The Lost & Found are compass-like mechanisms adorning the tops of these seemingly ordinary matching leather bracelets remain motionless until each bracelet is worn by a different creature. Once they're worn, the compass' arrows point rigidly in the direction of the matching band, without indicating height or depth. The arrows spin wildly if the bands are worn on different planes of existence.

Currently being held by Ronpip and Vimack.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Odd Goggles
item.description:
Infobox


The Odd Goggles appear to be a rotary series of crystal or glass lenses, held together in a metal cylinder. When worn, the lenses twist and flip within the cylinders to adjust to what the wearer is focusing on and analyzes objects up to 15ft away, so long as it is not behind any cover. When the object is properly identified by an unknown source, arcane script appears over the object and displays the name of an object. It can also identify a count of the objects by visual inspection, rough weight and size of the object, as well as a general material the object could be made out of. The accuracy of this identification is based on visual context, and can be skewed or misdirected.
If the object contains magic, the goggles may identify the object as it's mundane name, but add a question mark to it's displayed name, implying that it needs further identification. Additionally, the lenses will reveal the magical aura of the object, similar to Detect Magic, but does not reveal what that aura actually is or represents. A keen mind in Arcana can likely identify the school of magic the object is associated with, and likely it's origin if it was made on the material plane.
The goggles cannot identify people or creatures or plants, but it can identify what they are wearing. It can also vaguely see invisible objects, so long as it is not in tandem with spells or enchantments like Non-Detection.
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Ordinary Pot with Dirt
item.description:
Infobox


The Ordinary Pot with Dirt is just that. An ordinary clay pot with a generous amount of dirt in it. The dirt is oddly saturated with moisture, despite the lack of recent watering; and a perfectly sized hole appears in the center for a seed, should someone plant one within the pot...

Antillean has detected magic properties exist on the pot and dirt through the Odd Goggles.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Ordinary Pot with Dirt.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Solitaire of Inspiration
item.description:
Infobox


The Solitaire of Inspiration is a large blue opal surrounded in alternating cat’s eye gems and turquoise like the pupil of an eye on a sphere of oxidized copper, the item seems extremely valuable at first glance. If taken the time to meditate while staring into the eye, a gleam of inspiration can be drawn directly from it. The inspiration can come in the form of clarity, self manifestation, a possibility of the future, a memory from the past, or even a moment of dire threat or failure, potentially changing the fate of the user, should they use it. However, there is never a guarantee of a successful or preferable outcome!
If the holder can spend at least Ten Minutes meditating upon the sphere, they will earn an Inspiration point, as long as they do not already have one. Once the orb is meditated with, it will lose its magical charge until the next Dawn.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Solitaire of Inspiration.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Strange Stone Egg
item.description:
Infobox


The Strange Stone Egg is where the Arcane Wyvern Dorizoul hatched from.
Its origins are currently unknown, but it was sold to Vimack by Rozahhar in Massarnae, who did not know what it did and sold the egg cheap.
Rozahhar did not reveal where he had retrieved it from.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Strange Stone Egg.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: The Talisman of Pure Good
item.description:
Infobox


The Talisman of Pure Good is a mighty symbol of goodness. A creature that is neither good nor evil in alignment takes 6d6 radiant damage upon touching the talisman. An evil creature takes 8d6 radiant damage upon touching the talisman. Either sort of creature takes the damage again each time it ends its turn holding or carrying the talisman.
If you are a good cleric or paladin, you can use the talisman as a holy symbol, and you gain a +2 bonus to spell attack rolls while you wear or hold it.
The talisman has 7 charges. If you are wearing or holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 charge from it and choose one creature you can see on the ground within 120 feet of you. If the target is of evil alignment, a flaming fissure opens under it. The target must succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or fall into the fissure and be destroyed, leaving no remains. The fissure then closes, leaving no trace of its existence. When you expend the last charge, the talisman disperses into motes of golden light and is destroyed.

One Charge has been used by Evan against Vadathaus Horreneth; Failed.
One Charge has been used by Evan against Brand Diodah Urie; Failed.
One Charge has been used by Vimack against Elwin Petyra; Success.
The item has 4 charges remaining.
Currently being held by Vimack.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/The Talisman of Pure Good.md
item.dc:creator: K. B., Gunther

item.title: Tome of Endless Lore
item.description:
Infobox


The Tome of Endless Lore is a complex tome of near endless knowledge shared between Scribes of Fidchelle. A Scribe may write down a question or a subject of inquiry, in which the pages will become filled with the the words and notes of the vast knowledge provided by the other scribes. Information is almost entirely factual, but sometimes can be from a single perspective. The information is never wrong, but it can be incorrect or missing some information. Additional information can be provided by the Scribe to notate or add to the information already existing.
The tome cannot be read by non-scribes, nor can it be written into by non-scribes. The tome can be lost and summoned back to the scribe's pack at will. The tome cannot be destroyed. The tome can be reshaped to the scribe's needs. If the scribes feel another scribe is not being factual but opinionated by their entries, or that they will have a conflict of interest in writing information into the tome, the scribes can remove the tome from another scribe's possession and prevent summoning of the tome.
item.guid: Campaign/15 Magic Items/Wonderous Item/Tome of Endless Lore.md
